Posts.Content: Aug 9, 2008 03:13AM Shirlann wrote: Honey, this is not that unusual.  I do not excuse your medical team, far from it, but my best guess is that no one ever LOOKED at that part of your scan.  The docs/techs are over-worked and stressed out and frequently overlook things. That is why you are doing the best thing you can do, be your own best advocate.  Depending on the medical profession to always be right and help us is not gonna happen anymore.  Things have changed.  Watch and question everything.  We must all re-organize our thinking and expect very, very little from those who treat us. Get copies and go over all your blood work in the coming years, learn all you can so you can ask intelligent questions.  My husband is a diabetic, and he has been having terrible sugar drops at night, which are very dangerous.  I was idly looking at the Net, happened to look at his blood pressure medicine and the side effects include: "Hypoglycemic, dangerous, blood sugar drops when this medication is taken with Metformin".  Of course, he takes Metformin.  He has questioned his doc over and over, but he did not know.  Sheesh Gentle hugs, shirlann

Posts.Content: Sep 28, 2008 02:02AM Shirlann wrote: Well, most of us do not have pain with breast cancer.  But some women do.  With your family history, don't let them push you off, get a biopsy.  The ONLY way that anyone can tell what is in there is when the tissue is under a microscope.  Of course, this is impossible without finding a lump, and if you have an infection of some kind, there probably won't be a lump. BUT the next step (when this one is resolved), since your mom was so young, is you need to be tested for the BRCA gene.  And hopefully you will run into providers who agree with this.  We are very pushy on this site when we have women with strong family histories, especially if the family member was so young. It is hard not to worry, but we all did.  Be sure and come back and let us know what happens. Gentle hugs, Shirlann

Posts.Content: Sep 15, 2008 05:45PM - edited Sep 15, 2008 05:47PM by Shirlann AHEM, I am 73!  10 years past treatment, and I just got back from a 1300 mile trip up the Amazon.  The reason we are so scarce, is not a lot of women over 60 are not computer savvy.  The mean or average age for breast cancer is 63.  But you would never know it. Sore to the touch, might actually be good.  Usually, and I do qualify that comment, as I am definitely not a doc, the BC lumps are not sore, so it could be an infection of a milk gland, or some other infection. Yes, well tell that doc that without the Reader's Digest and no thanks to docs like him, I would not be here today.  I get my info from the Ladies Home Journal.  My degree is from there. All kidding aside, I found out about the Shingles Vaccine from the Ladies Home Journal, my doc certainly didn't tell me.  The jerk. I wonder if he would laugh if it was his testicle?  Don't let them intimidate you, it is your body and the only one you have.  You are responsible and careful, if they think that is funny, well, they are wrong. Good for you to keep on checking. Here's hoping we won't need my degree. Hugs and kisses, Shirlann

Posts.Content: Jun 26, 2008 11:00AM Shirlann wrote: Honey, this is just the best way they know to be sure you got the message.  It no doubt crossed over your phone calls.  Sounds to me like you have a super group.  If they are this careful to let you know. REMEMBER 80% of these "thingys" that we get called back for are benign.  So don't get your worry button pushed too soon.  It is hard, but this is what we go to be checked for.  Mammo's are no substitute for tissue under a microscope, but this does NOT MEAN you have cancer. So try, as best you can, to hang onto the 80% number.  Let us know, most of these things turn out just fine. Gentle hugs, Shirlann
Posts.Title: Is this the norm Carol315 lvtwoqlt

Posts.Content: Jan 9, 2008 04:49AM Shirlann wrote: Hi, I am a Triple Negative and 9 years post treatment.  When I got this news, little was known about it and I was GLAD, so see, things do change.  It just means you don't usually take hormones after treatment like the positive women do.  It means you have one less arrow in your cure quiver.  But so what!  The good news is this, after 2 to 3 years, the recurrence rate for triple negs drops to almost zero, while the other gals fade away more gradually.  So get to the 2 year mark and have a big party. And to address the issue of large tumors, boy that is a possibly bogus opinion!  In Dr. Susan Love's Breast Book she acknowledges that usually we like small tumors, but she said she had seen a lot of huge, lazy cancers that are taken out and never heard from again and a fair number of little bitty ones that metastasize quickly.  So again, the big cancer fear, no one really knows what will happen, but try not to worry about that one.  Size is somewhat of an indicator, but surely not for sure. Gentle hugs, Shirlann

Posts.Content: Oct 26, 2007 11:28PM Shirlann wrote: Hi sister, sorry you had to join us, but so glad you found us.  This is a tough thing to decide.  I understand and appreciate your holistic approach, just be aware that the first shot at this is the best. If you don't do the chemo/rads, and metastasize, there is no cure.  You can often live a long time, but this is not a situation where you can say, "Well, I'll try Holistic, and if it doesn't work, I will go to chemo and rads".  Usually, this is no longer an option. The radiation "cleans up" the area of the original tumor.  Chemo is systemic, cleans up any cells that might have escaped the breast. I would get Dr. Susan Love's Breast Book and read only as far as you need to.  The later chapters do not apply to you and will scare you.  She is a strong woman's advocate and I liked that. So think carefully, we have had numerous women over the years try the holistic route, and most have died.  I myself am a huge user and believer of vitamins.  They told me not to take them during treatment, I was shocked, I said "why".  It seemed to me that my poor body needed all the help it could get.  It was explained that if you send in mainly C, E, and A, they will go after the "free radicals" which are:  Chemo & Rads, so they are afraid they will interfere with treatment, maybe. (no one knows this for sure) So, think carefully, if you are healthy, you should tolerate these treatments well.  I myself am 9 years post treatment and still doing just fine. Gentle hugs, Shirlann

Posts.Content: Jan 12, 2008 03:02AM Shirlann wrote: First of all, it is IMPOSSIBLE to diagnose breast cancer, or any other cancer, without the tissue under a microscope.  The man may most definitely be correct, but this is not the normal procedure for a dr. to take.  I would run as fast as you can, elsewhere, not to his buddies, either.  Don't worry too much about time, it is important to keep moving, but most breast cancers are several years old before they can be found by any means so a few weeks to find another facility is not going to affect your outcome. If a tumor is large, often chemo is given first to shrink it.  In some cases you can then go on with a lumpectomy, just depends on size and whether or not you have lymph node involvement.  So this may be what you will eventually do.  But I don't like his approach or attitude and you don't have to put up with this treatment.  If it was a splinter, fine.  But this whole trip is long and nasty, and you have to have at least a working arrangment with your team. Posts.Content: Oct 16, 2008 01:25PM Shirlann wrote: Usually, sending slides to another facility is around $500.  This is money well spent.  So go to Johns Hopkins (call) or Dana Farber or Sloan-Kettering, these are among the top cancer centers in the world.  They will take your original slides and re-do the pathology.  (You can get these with a signed authorization), and send you a new pathology report, often with a treatment recommendation. This is sooo nice, when two groups agree.  Some women do this to more than one facility. I too kept my slides.  I KNOW where they are and I won't lose them. So ask the providers what this costs, and it should not be that much, back in 1993, when I sent mine to UCLA, it was only $125, but things are higher now. Good luck, Shirlann

Posts.Content: Aug 3, 2008 06:20PM Shirlann wrote: Well, darn it, that new symptom brings up another worry.  However, do not be too scared by this new idea, I just would feel remiss if I did not tell you.  There is a very rare form of breast cancer called Inflammatory.  It is so rare (and therefore very unlikely you have it) that most regular docs have never seen it.  It is often a rash, or little pimples, something like that.  The trouble with this type is that is can only be diagnosed with a biopsy.  Mammograms and ultrasounds will not reveal this rare type. I hope I haven't thoroughly scared you silly.  But if you don't know what might happen, and the people you are seeing don't know or care, I worry. So please don't worry about this, just stick it in the back of your mind. Gentle hugs, Shirlann

Posts.Content: Sep 15, 2008 09:03PM - edited Sep 15, 2008 09:10PM by Shirlann Well, I just left a woman who's sister decided that "slash/poison/burn" was not going to do for her.  That was 2 years ago.  Sadly, she is now terminal, with a gaping, puss filled hole in her breast.  I believe the sister was posting in the  "Triple Negative", thread. Make this decision very carefully.  Remembering that the first shot at this thing is the best.  And on the other hand, no one, I mean no one, can tell you with any certainty that you NEED chemo to survive or that you DO NOT NEED chemo to survive. All anyone has is the numbers.  If you recall, Lance Armstrong told them, "Hit me with all you have".  His doc/onc says now, "He had less than a 5% chance to make it".  Now, testicular is more responsive to treatment, and rarely recurs, so to compare him to us is truly apples and oranges. Breast cancer is notoriously fickle.  I would advise getting Dr. Susan Love's Breast Book, she is an advocate for women, and has our best interests at heart. And remember, what difference will it make, if you do not do chemo or rads, have no side effects, of course, but die.  Then you will have won the battle and lost the war. Don't get so caught up in the "what ifs?" of treatment.  There are literally thousands of us out here that were treated and are perfectly well.  I myself am 10 years post treatment and 73 years old, and just got back from a 1300 mile trip up the Amazon. Don't lose sight of the goal, worrying about side effects that may or may not occur.  I sailed through rads without a problem, I left for a trip to the Baja to see the whales 6 days after I finished the treatments.  I worked throughout.  You often see only the bad side effects, since few of us post:  " I had all the treatments, and I am just fine, tired of the whole thing, and shaken, but well".  You just never see that, and no one can guarantee that, but on the other hand, no one can guarantee you will survive without the recommended treatments. So you are taking a huge risk with your life on the chance you may have side effects?  Doesn't make sense to me. But, as always, it is a free country and your decisions will be honored.  But do go see the post of the sister who is grieving with her sister over her very bad decision to go with an unproven protocol. Gentle hugs, Shirlann
Posts.Title: need help rayne_23 Shirlann

Posts.Content: Sep 21, 2008 12:19PM Shirlann wrote: Well, "distant" recurrence is metastasis.  The oncs are just being kind.  You will die from this, not soon most likely, but there is no cure. So do not be confused.  Recurrence is simply the same breast cancer, just not completely eliminated.  "Distant" recurrence is the breast cancer in the lungs, bones, brain or liver.  This is what has happened to Elizabeth Edwards.  She is doing well, and many women live many years.  But don't be fooled into thinking it can be cured, it cannot. Hugs, Shirlann
Posts.Title: need help rayne_23 Shirlann

Posts.Content: Aug 3, 2008 10:31AM - edited Aug 3, 2008 10:34AM by Shirlann Hi, what I would urge you to do is find a breast cancer specialist or breast clinic ASAP.  NO ONE, and I mean NO ONE can tell what is in a lump until that tissue is under a microscope.  Period. These people make excellent guesses, but the also make many mistakes, I was one of them.  I was told, "Oh, this can't be breast cancer, see, your lump is smooth".  Well, 2 years later my smooth lump was diagnosed as Medullary BC, a small sub-type, and it is characterized by smooth edges. May I ask if you are going to different docs, but in the same town? Neighborhood? Clinic?, because they will back each other up, no matter what they think, themselves.  If you must, go out of that zip code.  And don't tell your new doc that you have been to many docs, this makes them wary of you (they are afraid of pro-active women, afraid you might sue).  So it is imperative you get out of the area you are in, and at first at least, don't talk much about your outrage, this scares them to death, and they will push you off so they don't have to deal with a "difficult" patient. This sounds awful, but after 7 years on this site, I have heard everything.  So you need to advocate yourself for yourself.  Do not be pushed off. Gentle hugs, Shirlann

Posts.Content: Jun 27, 2008 06:01PM - edited Jun 27, 2008 06:03PM by Shirlann I hear you mdb, but I have to say, my HMO would do anything rather than treat.  We pay a fixed amount yearly and the less they do, the more they make.  In fact, these docs get a bonus at the end of the year if they don't spend as much as the others in the group. In Europe, the situation is not exactly the same, but most docs are on a salary and don't make money from treatments. I am not disagreeing with you about the money mongers, we have had them, and we still do, but it just was not my case. I think what we have is a "set protocol" for each parameter.  So, no matter what, they do what the protocol says.  Even if it is silly, makes no sense, or is actually harmful.  This way they protect their rear ends and don't get sued as often.  I had a very small tumor, no nodes, and I wish that I had said no to rads, but we are so intimidated. I have no heart or lung issues 9 years later, but I have bone pain from either osteonecrosis (dead bone) or bone softening. So what I TRIED to do, and what I would now INSIST be done, is, get a lead apron and put it under your breast and over your abdomen.  I asked, but they said, "Oh, nothing gets anywhere except the breast".  Just not true.  So anyone who is contemplating this, MAKE them give you an apron, it sure is no skin off their nose. Hugs, Shirlann

Posts.Content: Oct 11, 2007 11:17AM Shirlann wrote: Well, dear sisters, this is called Post Traumatic Stress Syndrome. You do pretty well during all the hulabaloo, then, its "Okay, goodbye, have a nice life". It is scary and you are not yet mentally strong enough (or physically for that matter) to just be dropped. Recovering from this takes time. Anti-depressants help immensely. You feel abandoned, frightened, the family looks at you like you are crazy! "Hey, you are fine! Why aren't you happy?" This only makes you feel worse. PTSD takes a long time to get over. You have been through a life-threatening, frightful experience that may or not be over. You are entitled. No one who has not taken this walk HAS ANY IDEA of what the aftermath is like. Think Katrina. All your anchors are gone along with your confidence. This recovery takes time, but it does come. Gentle hugs, Shirlann

Of course you are worried, having had one cancer.  But this still does not have a lot to do with anything.  There are so many variables in all women, everything under the sun (actually, including the sun) that can be a culprit, after a while, you just say, what is done, is done, you can't undone it. Posts.Content: Sep 2, 2008 09:34AM Shirlann wrote: Hi my dear sisters, I am sure by now that most of you are aware that we frequently end up with Post Traumatic Stress Syndrome.  This is way it is.  Most of us get through treatment pretty well, and then just lose it, or, like all of you, end up with even more crap to deal with. I hope most of you have considered anti-depressants.  They were a life-saver for me.  I have always had depression problems, so I was especially susceptible, but what a God send! They are not addictive, although you need to get off them slooowly if you decide to do that.  They are not on the substance abuse list the government prints and they do not make you sleepy, or dopey. In fact, I didn't think they were working, then I began to hum softly to myself one day, and realised I hadn't hummed in months.  They take from 3 to 6 weeks to begin to have an effect. I urge all those not trying these blessings to think about it.  They sure knit up the raveled sleeve of care......(I would like to say I made that up, but it is Shakespeare). Other people are hopeless, they are cheery which makes you livid (how do they presume to have a clue what you are going through), or, they want to know who is saying your eulogy!).  Either reaction makes you want to decapitate them on the spot. Sheesh, gentle hugs, Shirlann

Posts.Content: Sep 28, 2007 09:35AM - edited Sep 28, 2007 09:38AM by Shirlann Hi, the stereotactic, is not as invasive as a biopsy, or, excisional biopsy.  So here is what I know.  Stereotactic Biopsy:  You lay down on a bed/cot with a hole in it.  Your breast kinda hangs through.  They take a bunch of tiny, tiny bits of breast tissue in the area they are looking at with a sorta punch thing.  This does not require any anesthetic, as it hurts so little. Needle Biopsy:  Here, you are given usually a local like a dentist does, and they stick a needle in and take out a small amount of tissue to put under the microscope. Excisional Biopsy:  This is what I had, they take you in the operating room, I just had local shots, and then they cut out the whole thing they think they see.  Mine was 7mm, so it was not much of a cut, and I was awake and chatting through the whole thing, no big deal, I waited around for an hour in a room and then went out to lunch with my hubby.  Now, some docs/surgeons want this done under a general anesthetic, where you are completely out.  This depends on the surgeon's preference, how deep, large or difficult the surgery might be.  So several things enter into the picture.  Your preference might be one of them.  Before I had this type of biopsy, they did a sonar with me sitting up and stuck a very thin needle into the area, checked that it was in the right place, and taped a cup over it and my husband drove me to the out-patient clinic nearby. There are very few nerves in the breast compared to other parts of the body.  And since you don't eat, digest, pee, poop, walk, talk or use the breast in any way, there is not much pain for most of us.  Of course, some people have very different experiences. Hugs, Shirlann

Posts.Content: Feb 12, 2008 05:34PM Shirlann wrote: Well, that is hard to answer.  If it is not cancer or if it is, size means to them that it will be a bit more of a surgery than they like to do under a local.  So for their comfort and ease, as much as yours, they like you out of it when they have to do a bit more surgery. Size does matter.  But it is only one of about a dozen things.  There are lots of women with big, old, lazy tumors that are taken out and never heard from again. And, some gals have pin sized tumors that metastasis quickly.  So there are a lot of things that go into this, just one of which is size. And you are not even diagnosed.  So as best you can, forget this, 80% of these "thingys" are nothing.  That is a huge number. Hugs, Shirlann

Posts.Content: Oct 2, 2008 03:06PM - edited Oct 2, 2008 03:11PM by Shirlann Hum, why would you need reconstruction after a lumpectomy?  Just curious.  I cannot even find my scar. I had a lumpectomy and I am totally satisfied with this decision.  I was a Triple Negative also.  I am 10 years post treatment and would not change a thing. So unless you have very tiny breasts or a very, very large tumor, I don't know why you would need reconstruction? Another interesting fact that no one truly understands, in Europe 70% of women (who are eligible) have lumpectomies.  In the US, this percentage is reversed.  The recurrence and met incidence are identical if you do radiation.  Also, it is impossible to completely remove all the breast tissue in a mast anyway.  You do get a couple of percentage points of advantage, not much, but you can recur in a mast scar, in the chest wall, etc.  So I am a little puzzled that so many women in the US have masts?  I surely understand the multi-focal issues, and the many cysts issues and the very, very dense breasts issues.  But if none of these things are you, I think you are doing the best thing.  And yes, you can always have a mast later.  Gentle hugs, Shirlann

Posts.Content: Dec 6, 2007 03:39PM Shirlann wrote: Hi, and welcome to these boards.  As I am sure you know, we cannot diagnose anything, but you have your appointment, and that is good.  The professionals really have the answers and the know how to tell you what is going on. Occasionally, a lymph node will get infected because of some other infection in the body.  The lymph system is designed to filter out "thingys" that might make us sick, and this is what is probably happening, although sometimes they just swell up.  But with another thing going on in your breast, it could be a number of things, most all of them benign. Yes, you can feel a lymph node if it is swollen.  If you think back, when you go into the docs for a flu or a cold, they will often run their hands over your neck, as these nodes are easy to feel, and often tell them that , yes, you do have an infection. But try not to worry, all will be revealed in a short time.  I wish you the best of luck. Gentle hugs, Shirlann

Posts.Content: Jul 25, 2008 09:59AM Shirlann wrote: Hi gals, this always worries me a little.  Having a double mastectomy does give you a few percentage points for no more cancer.  But women can and do get recurrences in the chest wall, in the scars, etc.  It is impossible to remove ALL the breast cells.  They are up your shoulder, under your arm, quite a lot is unreachable.  So do not have a double mast JUST to avoid cancer "ever again".  It can still come back.  So just do it for the right reasons. Gentle hugs, Shirlann

Posts.Content: Jul 31, 2009 04:03PM - edited Jul 31, 2009 04:03PM by Shirlann Hi, dear sisters, please remember, we have a sort of form of radiation sickness.  Your rad onc will deny this, but it is true. This can hit you early or late, some of us never have it at all.  Depends on your body and general helath too. I was helped greatly by 1000mg of Vitamin C daily, with a good B Complex, Fish Oil and Calcium. I don't know if any of this really helps, it is impossible to tell, but sure can't hurt to try and get your energy back. (DO NOT start this vitamin therapy until AFTER treatment is over) I know that for some of us it is the whole thing.  Basically a year of fear, panic, pain and feeling ill.  This causes a form of Post Traumatic Stress Syndrome.  Just like the vets.  So give yourselves and your poor bodies a break and rest all you can and build up your bodies with good, fresh food, lots of water and plenty of rest. Gentle hugs, Shirlann  (Getting close to 11 years post treatment)

Posts.Content: Oct 9, 2007 09:37AM - edited Oct 9, 2007 06:26PM by Shirlann Hmmm, you have a wide variety of symptoms. This tends to be difficult for docs to know quite where to start, as you are finding out. Of course, I am not a doctor, but I have been around these boards for a long time and I think most of the girls would agree, never heard of leg lumps associated with breast cancer. This sounds like something is bothering your lymph nodes, so the docs need to find out what this is. Lymph nodes, as you probably well know, are there to stop or prevent "things" from moving on to other areas in your body. They are often associated with infection somewhere, but just as often with auto-immune diseases. I don't think you could normally notice lymph nodes unless they are enlarged, hard or hurting. If I were you, and I could, I would go to a major center, like Mayo Clinic, and get a complete "work up". Probably your own doc can do this too, if going out of town is not an option. You need a full-on blood panel, urinalysis, etc. Just a really complete physical. So many things affect the lymph system, it really does take a doctor to even begin to find out what is causing your problems. Could you have breast cancer? Yes, you could, and that would be part of a complete physical. You can also have more than one thing going on. This makes diagnosis difficult. I would just keep pursuing these symptoms and not just give up. If your current doctor seems uninterested, go elsewhere. But keep pushing until you are satisfied. Gentle hugs, Shirlann

Posts.Content: Apr 19, 2009 07:00PM Shirlann wrote: Hi everyone, when I wrote about the second opinion, I mean it.  All you need are your daughters original slides and mammos and you can call Sloan-Kettering, Dana Farber, Johns Hopkins, any major cancer center, ask the cost, and FedEx the whole lot to them for a second reading of the slides.  Since I was a victim of a wrongly read set of slides, I know better than to trust that the pathology report is gospel.  It very well may be, but it also may not be.  They finally sent my slides to White Plains, New York. So at little cost (about $500) and without any more trauma for your daughter, you can get a second opinion.  I would most certainly do this.  I would have been treated for the wrong cancer if I had not gone to UCLA (or sent my slides, I should say). I guess my experience makes me not as trusting of ANY pathology report.  If you send those slides to a world class cancer center, where the pathologist does NOTHING but breast slides, you can be confident that your diagnosis for Hannah is correct. Gentle hugs, Shirlann

Posts.Content: Sep 29, 2008 04:53PM - edited Sep 29, 2008 04:55PM by Shirlann Tonyia, let's start out by getting one thing straight.  Stop feeling like these providers are doing you a favor by taking your concerns seriously,  You have every right to get the answers that give you peace of mind and answers to your questions. This is your body, the only one you have, so stop feeling like you are annoying them or that you are a hypochondriac.  You are a concerned consumer, paying for this service, and you are not a charity case. Now, with that settled.  MRI's are often a very good tool in helping diagnose what is going on. Do not pay any attention to Lay people's opinions.  It is true that breast cancer usually does not hurt.  But sometimes it does.  Your age is a factor, but we have had women as young as 22 with breast cancer.  Your age makes it less likely, but not for sure.  And so, just smile, and continue until YOU are satisfied with answers. Be assured the only way that a diagnosis is for positive sure, is when the actual tissue is under a microscope.  All the other stuff is just good pointers, that's all.  Mammograms alone are about 70% accurate.  MRI's show cancer, but they also show every other thing that lights up. So again, this is a wonderful, helpful tool, but not a given answer.  So I would suggest that you continue to be persistent, do not cry, or act hysterical, just be firm, and insist that you get the answers you want.  If the people you are dealing with push you off with half or vague conclusions.  Go elsewhere.  Some of our women have gone to more than one facility.  This is just what many of us had to do.  I went to UCLA, not happy with the conclusions I got with my local bunch of bozos.  I loved UCLA, I could not believe the professionalism.  What a night and day difference in competence, care of the patient, the pathologist at UCLA did nothing but breast cancers and I was satisfied with the results.   Remember, this is your body, your life and you only get one.  If the providers are pooh poohing you, politely go elsewhere.  This is not a game. Gentle hugs, Shirlann

Posts.Content: Oct 13, 2008 04:37PM - edited Oct 13, 2008 04:39PM by Shirlann Hi honey, and welcome.  It is not unusual for the doc to have some information in his hand when you come in.  With a negative mammo and a negative ultrasound, he can rule out several things.  Most breast cancers, with the exception of just one or two types that are rare, are found this way, with the tests he has sent you for.  So he can concentrate on finding out what is causing this boil/pimple/eruption. So there is no point in him seeing you, really, unless he has x-ray vision, he will depend on his radiology reports to help you.  This is not uncommon. One thought, I am sure, at your age, that you just have what you describe, an infection, this can be from a hair follicle, or any number of things.  One exception is IBC, which is so rare, I hate to worry you with it, but it is Inflammatory Breast Cancer.  It is not detectable with a mammogram or ultrasound, only with a biopsy. I tell you this, not to scare you silly, but just so you have this question to ask him, and if this thing does not clear up in a reasonable time, which it most likely will, you will know a little bit about this very unusual breast cancer. Gentle hugs, Shirlann
Posts.Title: Tests before examination Kristinr978 Shirlann

Posts.Content: Nov 10, 2007 01:18AM - edited Nov 10, 2007 01:20AM by Shirlann Hi honey, with your history, this is the time to demand treatment. I kinda am worried about an odd sub-type of breast cancer that is very rare, so I hope I am not scaring you, I don't want to do that, but you need to be aware of Inflammatory Breast Cancer.  Why?  Well, it is rare, it does NOT show up on either a mammo or an UltraSound, it can be diagnosed ONLY with a biopsy.  I am sure this is not what you have, but I would go to a breast center, if you can, and be sure to bring up this type, many docs/oncs have never even seen this. I surely do not want to scare you half to death over nothing, but I don't like the way they are treating you and I don't like the family history AT ALL. At the very least you should be seen frequently, and by all means have the BRCA gene test done.  So please forgive me, I probably shouldn't have even mentioned this type of BC, and obviously, this is not what was wrong 8 years ago.  So with a little luck, nothing serious is wrong this time either. I am beginning to blather. Gentle hugs, Shirlann PS:  You are not too young to have breast cancer, although it is much rarer at your age, but in my mind, your family history overrides your age.

I, myself am a strong believer in genetics, not that it does any good to feel that way, since so far, they don't have much to fix that with, but my husband's dad smoked 3 packs a day from the age of 12 till he died at 86.  Not one symptom of even emphysema, let alone lung cancer.  No cancer in his family, either.  But that theory has a ways to go. Posts.Content: Jun 21, 2008 07:21PM Shirlann wrote: Hi Totaldo, what you need to consider is, if you do not do chemo, if this is the protocol for your case, it is possible, certainly not for sure, but possible that you could have the cancer return.  Of course, it could return anyway, but if you do the chemo, you will know you have done all you could, and so will have no reason for any regrets. If it is just a recurrence, that is not too bad, it can be re-treated, but if you metastasize (the BC moves to your liver, bones, brain or lungs) you are NOT curable.  Now, many of these women live a long, long time, but they will eventually die of breast cancer, in this case, a few months of misery seem like a pretty good trade.  Just be sure you understand your first shot at this is the best one. Gentle hugs, Shirlann

Posts.Content: May 5, 2008 11:58PM Shirlann wrote: Hi Apple, NO, YOU CAN'T IGNORE THIS! If you think your household would be in a mess if you treat your cancer, how in the heck could they handle you sick for two years and then dead? Think, girl, think.  If you are active in your church or any club, ask for help with an evening meal.  Most people like you are very, very independent, but toss that aside, and admit to one and all that you have to have some help.  Line up everyone. Tackle this as you would a tornado, or a flood, would you just fall over in the water and drown, leaving a group of wonderful kids without a mom, just because you were busy?  NO, OF COURSE NOT! Breast cancer is something that is no fun, but in many cases, it is not that bad either.  I had a lumpectomy, radiation and worked through the whole thing (admitedly, no where near as hard as you work), I was 63 that was 9 years ago and I am fine.  I am so glad I didn't ignore this cancer, I just got back from the Amazon.  Life is full of such wonderful things, you can't be serious that because you are busy you don't have time to treat something as treatable as this? So get with it girl, you are obviously the type who will take this in stride and just add it to the long, long list. I don't know you yet, but just from reading your post, I don't want you to go prematurely. Gentle hugs, Shirlann

Posts.Content: Jun 14, 2008 06:36PM - edited Jun 14, 2008 06:39PM by Shirlann Hi Randy, so good of you to be such a wonderful husband, it is such a blessing for your wife. I got the same stupid run around, a lot of us do.  I was told it was nothing for two years, then when they finally decided it WAS something it took them 3 months to get to the biopsy, and they thought it was Lymphoma.  I went to UCLA.  Thoroughly disgusted. But that was 9 & 1/2 years ago and I am fine today.  You have every reason to expect your wife will grow old with you, 90% of us recover and go on with our lives. I like Dr. Susan Love's Breast Book, just for you.  It will explain so much.  Don't read the later chapters, you won't need them and they are depressing.  Also, I took a small tape recorder since my husband and I were so upset we ended up arguing over what was said and this recorder solved that problem. This is not an easy journey, it is so long a lot of women end up with Post Traumatic Stress Syndrome.  But truly, especially with no nodes positive, your wife should be just fine.  Almost all the women I started out there with are long gone on with their lives. But please post often, someone can answer just about anything, and we have a few resident wizards.  Like Beesie, Beth, and Leaf, women who truly have done their homework. You whine away, that is just what you get to do here.  Tear out your hair, cyber style, since we don't know you too well yet.  When we get to love you as we always do our newbies, then you have to be careful!  Gentle hugs, Shirlann

Posts.Content: Jun 20, 2008 07:53AM - edited Jun 20, 2008 07:53AM by Shirlann Hi Kimberlyn, you are in a good place.  The surgeon is just being a surgeon. (Not to say you shouldn't go elsewhere)  Did you know the difference between surgeons and God?   .............God KNOWS he's not a surgeon!  Now, you are not in the mood for silly jokes, but what he suggested is pretty much what most suggest at your stage with one node.  However, as the sisters have already told you, you can go elsewhere, for sure, to someone with a better bedside manner. My bunch of jokers had me wait 2 years, because, in the words of another jack-ass surgeon, "If it was a cancer (referring to my obvious lump) it would be spikey".  Fast-forward two years, now it really shows up.  I had test after test (everything but a biopsy) and nothing showed up.  Finally, finally, finally, they did a biopsy and they thought I had Lymphoma.  They sent my slides to White Plains, NY and I had an odd sub-type of BC called Medullary, which is characterized by "smooth edges".  I was so mad, I was furious, bunch of idiots. So I got my original mammo's (the one with the lump was "missing") and my slides and went to UCLA.  They agreed with everything, so I went back and got treatment.  That was 9 & 1/2 years ago.  I am fine. Please don't feel alone.  If we had all the nitwit medical personnel in a line, it would stretch to the moon.  But do remember that speed (in most cases, not all) is not that important.  Most breast cancers, by the time you can find them by any means are 8 to 12 years old, so it is not unreasonable to either get a good 2nd opinion or change surgeons. Gentle hugs, Shirlann

Posts.Content: Dec 26, 2007 12:07PM - edited Dec 26, 2007 12:08PM by Shirlann Hi sister, and welcome to this site.  You do know you hit the breast cancer jackpot!  With DCIS, there is no danger of dying.  This is the very best diagnosis you can get. There are not a lot of places who do "all" the things you will need.  Usually you have a GP who sends you to a mammo place, who sends you to a surgeon, and then so on.  But there are some.  Cancer Centers of America is the one I have heard about, and of course, the world famous ones like Sloan-Kettering, Dana Farber, etc.  And then there are Breast Specialist Centers.  If you have that available, that is great. So happy you found us.  Sorry you had to, but again, you are in fine shape to make a full and uneventful recovery.  You will need to be super vigilant in the future, but still, no danger of mortality. The "lump" is no doubt fluid.  You may need to go back to your surgeon's office and have this aspirated.  No big deal, but the build-up is normal and quite painful.  Some of us have drains that hang out of the incision, that can be emptied.  Just your surgeons decision. So most of us just move to one discipline to another.  There are not many places where it is all in one place.  At least not here in San Diego. Sorry you had to join us, very happy with your diagnosis, so come and post often and other gals will be along soon with ideas. Gentle hugs, SHirlann

Posts.Content: Sep 9, 2008 09:19AM Shirlann wrote: Hi sisters, I have been around so long, I have moss on my computer forearms!  But I have a couple of suggestions that maybe you have not thought of, no magical cures, but a couple of ideas. People have found, by accident, that the Anti-Depressive, Effexor, helps some women a lot with menopausal symptoms.  So this might be worth a try. I take vitamins:  Believe me, no magic bullet here, but remember, your immune system, your mental health and your poor body have taken a huge hit.  And it might need some help getting back to more normal. I take, have taken for many, many years:  1000mg of C, a very good B Complex, Co-Enzyme 10, 1000units of D, folic Acid, Fish oil, and a bunch of stuff that may or not have any use.  Green Tea capsules, Cranberry capsules, Grapeseed capsules, a multiple for the trace elements (they do not contain enough of the C, B or D to do any good. So, I have a little box, for me and my husband and I fill it once a week and just chug these down.  I have never had fatigue (but, of course, who knows why?) and I hardly ever get colds, any opportunistic little infections. So while this is surely not a cure, it can't hurt and might help.  At least you feel that you are doing something to get back to normal. Gentle hugs, Shirlann PS:  Don't ask your doc, unless you want to get slammed!!!!!

Posts.Title: lumpectomy vs. mastectomy? kira Shirlann

Posts.Content: May 16, 2008 05:15PM - edited May 16, 2008 05:20PM by Shirlann A lot of women are going for mastectomies.  In Europe, 70% have lumpectomies, here in the US, the statistics are reversed.  I had a lumpectomy and I have been fine for 9 years. One thing I hope everyone knows is that while there are many reasons for a mast, multi-focal disease, different things in the breast, DCIS plus IDC, etc., big tumor, small breast, etc., etc.  NEVER having to worry about breast cancer in that breast is not one of the reasons.  You can have a recurrence in the chest wall, the scar, etc.  Breast tissue is up your arm, under your arm, etc.  Can't all be removed.  So while a mast is often very, very necessary, never having to worry about that breast is not true, a mast just gives you a slight edge over lumpectomy. Gentle hugs, Shirlann
Posts.Title: lumpectomy vs. mastectomy? kira Shirlann

Posts.Content: Sep 20, 2007 04:27PM Shirlann wrote: Hi and welcome. You will need a test of your lymph nodes. And that should be a Sentinel Node Biopsy. This is a newer test that is not as invasive as an axillary dissection (translation, they just grab a hunk of flesh under your arm, send it to pathology, and the pathologist digs around and dissects some lymph nodes. The sentinel, obviously, is much less invasive. Of course, ideally, we would all like to be treated at Sloan-Kettering in New York, or Johns Hopkins. Also Dana Farber, Brigham & Womens, Mayo, there are a lot of super-duper cancer centers. M.D. Anderson in Houston too. But if that is not reasonable, you can find a surgeon you trust, have the surgery and the lymph node test and then, get the original slides, original mammo's and copies of your records and send all of this to one of the major cancer centers. Usually you need to call first, find out the cost and the address and then with a written authorization, collect all these things and mail them off. All but MD Anderson (they don't do outside work anymore) will re-do the pathology and send you a new report with treatment recommendations. If this agrees with your local docs/oncs/surgeons, then you can confidently carry on. Of course, if you have the funds, I would go to a world renowned cancer center at once. The advantage is that often the cancer centers have a pathologist or even a whole department devoted to just your cancer (breast, prostate, etc.) instead of a pathologist who maybe 10% of his work is breast cancers, and of course, every other thing that comes down the road. Just makes sense that a doc specializing in your cancer is better informed, is up on the latest treatment, etc. Good luck, and keep posting, Shirlann

Posts.Title: Well, this sucks Sparkytheimp cmharris59

Posts.Content: Dec 7, 2008 06:49PM Shirlann wrote: This is always up to you, but experience with lots of moms and dads tells us to calmly say, I have cancer, use the word, so he won't hear it from the neighbors.  Tell him you may not always feel real good, but the doctors will take good care of you. Ask him to help, (even if he doesn't), say, "The whole family is a team, and we can and will beat this and I will be good as new".  Could you:  feed the pets, fold the clothes, bring in the trash barrels, get the mail, (age appropriate). Years ago, people did not tell children anything.  But with something like this, that will take time to recover from, the children are like little antennas, they hear you cry, they hear muffled phone calls, they are amazingly intuitive, and will always think the worst unless included in a lot of the talk.  (Obviously, you don't want to scare the kids, but you would be surprised how good and solid they are if they feel like part of the team) Also, many of the moms on this site have told the school teacher, just for  a heads up.  And so if your child acts out or anything, they are kinder.  But it is good to get anyone and everyone up to date and on one page.  Then there is no "Shhhsh, so and so is listening!".  That scares them silly. Gentle hugs, Shirlann

Fatigue is from the rads. You are getting a very low dose, but radiation sickness is still part of the deal, despite what the radiation oncologist tells you, I know my own body. One night, by husband had told some friends we would go out to dinner with them, I went, but the next day I could hardly get out of bed. I learned my lesson. Posts.Content: Jul 27, 2008 07:09PM Shirlann wrote: Hi Sly, I do not know as much as some of the other women do about the bloody discharge, but I do know that shape if pretty iffy.  Lots of BC's are "spikey", of course, I had a smoothlump, that turned out to be a small sub-type, but there are very few like this.  I think the little stinkers can be just about any shape, and it is hard to even know what shape they are without removing them. I want to welcome you to this board and hope and pray your stay will be very short.  With your family history, you are very wise to be super vigilant.  You might want to see a geneticist, there are several genes that can help you with decisions on whether to be super aggressive in finding out things.  One is the BRCA gene.   You are quite young, and that is in your favor.  AND 80% of these "thingys" are benign, that also is a big number and one you need to hug while this nightmare wait goes on.  Every one of us had this (always over a weekend), and it is torture.  The next thing you need to know is that about 80 to 85% of us recover completely and are just fine.  So even if this is cancer, you are very likely to have a rocky few months, for sure, but a full recovery is not only possible, but very likely. I am 9 & 1/2 years post treatment and fine.  There are literally thousands of us out here, nobody says much, but people who have been through this and gone on to have a great life are way in the majority. So post often, and we will help all we can. Gentle hugs, Shirlann

Posts.Content: Sep 5, 2010 03:33PM - edited Sep 5, 2010 03:34PM by Shirlann Well, you have been diagnosed with cancer, so the discharge could well be connected.  When you see your oncologist, he can tell you what this is.  This whole journey is sooo long.  You get little bits of info from each provider (regular doc, oncologist, radiologist, etc.) and it drove us all crazy until everything comes together and you can see the whole picture. Posts.Content: Nov 24, 2007 10:17AM Shirlann wrote: Hi sister, I don't want to throw in ugly information, but I am sure you are aware that mastectomy does NOT mean you can never get breast cancer again. You do have some percentage points advantage. However, it is impossible to get "ALL" the breast tissue out, and you can have a recurrence in the chest wall or in the scar. Breast tissue extends up the front of your breast/chest and under your arm, you cannot get it all removed. So not to be a negative voice, just be sure you are well informed. Dr. Susan Love in her Breast Book, says that she almost prefers a lumpectomy (when this is the right choice, and there are plenty of very good reasons for masts) because with a recurrence, she has tissue to work with instead of trying to dig into the chest wall. With your non-invasive type, I think a double mast would be big time overkill. Especially with the time that has gone by since your diagnosis. But, as always with this thing, you must make the choice. (I just love it, the one time we really need good medical advice/opinions and they tell us WE need to decide). Last time I checked I didn't have a medical degree! But I sure understand what you are saying, and as always, it is your decision. Hugs, Shirlann

Posts.Content: Oct 29, 2007 02:00PM Shirlann wrote: Well, for me, the stereotactic was not much, felt like little pinches, kinda hard to describe.  They lay you on a table like thing, with a hole, and your breast hangs in the hole.  Then it is like a horse fly bite, way less than a bee, but more than a mosquito (which we don't often feel at all).  But something stings, and they do about 12 to 18, depending.  Some of the gals have had anesthesia, I think, a local, but I did not.  However I did take a Valium that morning. Then, if this tissue shows anything odd, (wait,wait,wait, again) they would usually go to a excisional biopsy, or if they think it is quite small, like mine, they just took it out, with a local.  Nothing to that. Don't worry about the time, it is fine.  I was tested for 3 months before they got a diagnosis, and usually, that old thinking about speed is not generally valid anymore.  Not to say some types of BC they do need to be quick, but most of them, speed is not important, whithin reason.  You are NOT a baby, this whole thing scared the beejesus out of every single one of us.  We were all terrified.  Ask you doc for one prescription of Zanax, or Valium or something to use the night before to sleep and during the test in the morning.  Then you will have something to take until you get the test results.  This is a long drawn out terrifying ordeal.  But you have every reason to believe it is benign, as 80% of these "thingys" are benign. So, no, you are not a wuss, we each and everyone felt exactly the same way you do. Post often, with any old thing, we are usually always here. Gentle hugs, Shirlann

Posts.Content: Sep 13, 2008 05:12PM - edited Sep 13, 2008 05:20PM by Shirlann Honey, I never had any scans or checks.  It is totally optional.  In Dr. Susan Love's Breast Book, she kinda downplays this approach, thinking that you have all you need to handle right now and what real purpose does more checking accomplish?  So don't feel you are necessarily missing anything. Besides, the MRI you already had would have lit up like a neon light if there was cancer anywhere else in your body, so in effect, you had the best test possible. He feels you have been diagnosed early enough not to worry about this.  And if it has spread, you will know it soon enough.  I know that not all the women agree with this approach, but since with metastasis (not to confused with recurrence) there is no cure, so what's the rush to find this out? Again, trust me, this is a very individual issue.  And depending on you and your personal feelings, you can generally get this testing done if you want.  Your doc feels it is so remote a possiblity that it is not worth it.  I agree with him. So don't feel bad about feeling bad.  This whole journey is a frickin' nightmare, it was for all of us and what he knows, and you need to hang onto, is about 80% of us recover completely.  That is a big number.  I don't mean to minimize the journey, or the terror, or the lingering fear we all have, but I am 10 years post treatment and fine.  I met a lady at the dog park who had BC in 1985, and she told me she often forgets which side it was on.  Women just don't talk about it.  In my small bible class, as I blubberingly told them "I have breast cancer!", 3 women (in a group of about 20) piped up, "Me too".  I was shocked.  One was 22 years post double mast, one was 17 years post treatment, and the other one 11 years post treatment.  We are all still doing just fine, 10 years later. This is very scary, but come and post often, rant and rave and cry.  We all did.  You are in a huge sisterhood, just remember, most of us come out in one piece. Every headache is never a headache, it is brain mets, no back or bone pain (which I have all the time) is never just getting older, it is mets.  This thinking gets a lot better as time goes by. Gentle hugs, Shirlann

No one knows for positively certain what is what until that lump is in a jar and the tissue is under a microscope. They have a lot of tools and they are an enormous help, but the proof of the pudding is the biopsy. As you can see, most of us here are BC gals, so we are unusually pro-active. Some of us have been pushed off and lived to regret it. Me for one. So you do get a somewhat angry (some of us) response to being belittled or blown off. Just pick yourself up and go elsewhere. Posts.Content: Sep 1, 2008 09:50AM - edited Sep 1, 2008 09:53AM by Shirlann Hi Nancy, the NIH, National Institutes for Health and the CDC, Centers for Disease Control are good places to find on the net.  They track these things.  The big, gigantic problem of course, is that cancer does not strike you down like a cyanide capsule.  I think of the boys who were lined up in Nevada (soldiers) and purposely exposed to various levels of our atom and hydrogen bomb tests there.  Some died pretty soon, some much later, and some not at all prematurely.  That is the big conundrum.  Some people seem to have an "anti-cancer" gene or something that protects them, that's the one we want to find. What I find unconscionable about this sort of thing is they got tons of data from Hiroshima and Nagasaki, so why do it all over again?  Grant money?  I am getting cynical. My father-in-law smoked 3 packs a day from about age 7.  Died  at 80, didn't even have emphysema, but none of his large family had any cancer.  So hard to figure this thing out.  Hugs, Shirl
Posts.Title: Cancer cluster - how to determine? NancyD sbmolee

Posts.Content: Sep 14, 2007 05:35PM - edited Sep 14, 2007 05:36PM by Shirlann Well you have a lot on your plate. You did not say how old you are or if you are done with menopause. These things will affect any decisions you make. All anyone can do is put themselves in your shoes. If I were you, and I had my family complete, I would get rid of everything. I am in an HMO, and we cannot "ask" for oophectomy, just for prophylactic reasons, but I wish my ovaries and uterus were gone. I read in one book years ago (so I don't know if this info is true) that we have 4 times the risk of Ovarian Cancer because we have had breast cancer. This is just my own personal opinion, I don't have any medical training. So as usual, you will need to read, read, read. Listen and put all the info together to decide for yourself what you want to have done. Don't feel a particular rush, you need to recover from one thing before you go on to another, to give your body a chance to recoup and not fall victim to some nasty germ waiting to pounce on compromised immune systems. Good luck, and keep us informed. Gentle hugs, Shirlann

Posts.Content: Jan 8, 2008 06:05PM - edited Jan 8, 2008 06:05PM by Shirlann I just caught up with this thread.  Oh Barb, I am so glad the surgery went well.  I laughed and laughed about your hubby, it was so cute.  I know the chemo is no fun, but you can do it.  It seems that after the surgery, when we know that is over, everything is easier.  No one likes the surgery part. It is amazing about the anesthetic, isn't it?  You never are that "out" with regular sleep.  You have no concept that any time has passed.  Really wierd.  I never worry about the anesthetic at all, I think it is great.  My grandmother had all her children except one with nothing at all.  Then her friend had ether, (It was new, then)  she cried and cried about how wonderful the drug was, she named her little girl, ETHER!  I am not kidding.  So I always felt, good, I am not there, nothing to worry about this.  If I never wake up, the Lord will be waiting, I HOPE, and if not, well, that's the way it goes.  Never bothered me. Anyway, it is good to catch up with you now that you are so far along this journey.  Gentle hugs, Shirlann
Posts.Title: Why am I not upset? Barbara1 Mary-Lou

Posts.Content: Jan 8, 2008 09:40PM - edited Jan 8, 2008 09:42PM by Shirlann Hey Barb, sweetie, the steroids keep you feeling better. They really do. They keep your appetite up, so you don't get all skinny like Lindsay Lohan, and you feel better. If you don't take them, I think some of the gals started out not taking them, you won't feel as good. So I would give it a try. You can always stop. Have you had a bad experience with them before? We all know that long term steroid use is not good, but this short sprint will not harm you long term. But if you are dead set against them, of course you do not have to take them. This is not Russia. Now radiation, I just sailed through that. I had my zap at 3pm, after work, went home and did NOTHING. Of course, I was 63, others have little ones or jobs that are more demanding than mine was. I did not burn (I know I was lucky there) and I left for a trip down the Baja to see the whales 6 days after I finished. Others, not so lucky. But no matter what happens with rads, it is not 1/10th as bad as chemo. So try not to waste a lot of time worrying about that. One day at a time, baby steps. I was kinda like you, Barb, I did not cry, I think with my dad's horrible family of cancer relatives, I kinda knew it was coming somewhere. When people talk about life-altering events. This is one. I, of course, instead of moving to africa to help the people, began a retail therapy course and I am still paying off my credit cards! I don't advise that! I thought I was dying and someone else would pay them NOT!!!! It is a big change, but that too begins to fade as you move back into your normal routine. I was very busy right then, so I just kinda got lucky, a lot depends I think on what else is happening in your life. You are a sweetheart and a kick-in-the-pants, I can tell, I wish you were nearby. Anywhere near San Diego? I would love to meet you. Hugs and kisses, Shirlann
Posts.Title: Why am I not upset? Barbara1 Mary-Lou

Posts.Content: Jan 29, 2008 02:34PM Shirlann wrote: Barbara, honey, definitely change oncs.  I had a horrible surgeon, but his part was over quickly, then I got a perfectly wonderful onc.  You certainly don't really feel up to "doctor hunting", but I would get out of the negative influence.  I think you should expect to be perfectly well.  We have had so many women with positive nodes who come out just fine.  It is just the bodies mechanism to stop things from moving on.  So the nodes did just what they were supposed to do. You will get well,  and we will all celebrate together, sisters forever! Gentle hugs, Shirlann
Posts.Title: Why am I not upset? Barbara1 Mary-Lou

Posts.Content: Oct 26, 2007 07:57PM - edited Oct 26, 2007 07:58PM by Shirlann Hi Barbara, I am 9 years post treatment, and trust me, there are thousands of us out here who have made this nasty journey and are just fine. The thing is, all the gals I started with were mostly younger, I am now 72, and they have gone back to their families and jobs and lives. I am retired and I love this site so much for all the comfort and info I got when I needed it, I stick around. I have a small bible class, about 25 of us, when I weepingly told them I had BC, 3 women piped up.  THREE out of 25.  One was 22 years post double mast, one was 17 years post treatment and one 11 years out.  I was stunned.  You can add 9 years to all these numbers, these gals are still in my bible class and doing just fine. I met a gal at the dog park and she told me she had BC in 1985 and sometimes forgets which side it was on. This is no fun.  It is a hard, long journey, I don't mean to make light of it at all.  Some women have horrible experiences, some not so bad, and some not too bad at all.  One never knows.  But what I do know is I have about 20 women who I have known for years, that I met on this site and they are all fine and well. You will be too. Gentle hugs, Shirlann
Posts.Title: Why am I not upset? Barbara1 Mary-Lou

Posts.Content: Oct 31, 2007 09:23PM - edited Oct 31, 2007 09:24PM by Shirlann Hi Barbara, anything you can do that makes you feel somewhat in control and is an attempt at helping get this thing on the run, you do it.  It helps a lot just to try to do a few things we all know we need to do anyway. I like Dr. Susan Love's Breast Book, if you read the later chapters, it can be scary, so just stay where you are in treatment.  Don't delve farther, you don't need to read things that will not happen to you. And I took a small tape recorder with me and didn't have to take notes or remember, they throw a lot of info at you and you don't even remember where you parked your car! Oh, today, on the evening news, they said we could cut cancer in HALF if we ate less fat, so there, you are on the right track. Anyway, it is sad you had to come here, but we love you and you are a sister to us.  So post often and tell us what is happening. Gentle hugs, Shirlann

Posts.Content: Aug 18, 2008 12:55PM - edited Aug 18, 2008 12:56PM by Shirlann If the breast cancer has spread to the lungs, usually, they do not remove the lobe.  Because if the breast cancer has metastasized here, it is already in her system and therefore surgery is not usually the treatment, They can and do use chemo and radiation, and it often reduces the size, or in some cases removes the tumor, allowing for a long time of nice living.  So this is what I have usually heard from the met board.  The pathologist should be able to tell easily if the lung thing is breast cancer.  If he can't, take the slides to another pathologist, or send them (call first) to a top notch cancer center, such as Sloan-Kettering. Sounds a little strange that they can't tell the difference, they tell the difference all the time.  Are you at a large facility?  I would definitely get those slides somewhere else before you decide what to do.  You are right, the quality of life issue is huge, and losing a partial lung with other health issues seems extreme.   So definitely get a second opinion, one way or the other. Gentle hugs, Shirlann
Posts.Title: Where to go from here? chipdog3 chipdog3

Posts.Content: Aug 19, 2008 08:57PM Shirlann wrote: Hi Sandy, you can call Sloan-Kettering in New York, just ask information, Dana Farber, in Baltimore, I am not sure where Johns Hopkins is, but those are 3 of the best, of course, Mayo, or UCLA, works too.  Ask them for the oncology department, breast cancer division.  Hopefully, you will get a live person.  Ask if they will re-do your slides and how much.  Then, Fed-Ex the whole lot to them and they will re-do the slides and give you a new pathology report.  Some women have done this more than once.  I have never heard of not being able to tell what kind of cancer cells a pathologist is looking at.  HUH??? To get the original slides and mammo's, sometimes they will send them on for you, but I prefer to call the facility, ask what they need (legally, just a signed authorization) and if you have a fax, they can fax the forms to you for your mom to sign, then go in and get them yourself.  There are services in large cities that will do this for you, but of course, this is expensive. So this is how it is done, they do not need to see your mom, necessarily, so the cost is so much less.  I only paid $125, but that was almost 10 years ago, now, it is more like $500, but it is still a lot cheaper than airfare, hotels, etc. PM me if you need any more info.  Oh, I kept all my stuff myself, even though I promised to return it, I know I won't lose any of it, in case I need it at some later time. Hugs, Shirlann
Posts.Title: Where to go from here? chipdog3 chipdog3

Posts.Content: Mar 20, 2012 07:17AM Shirlann wrote: Oh gee, in the US, Sloan-Kettering, MD Anderson, Johns Hopkins,Mayo Clinic, Dana Farber, Cancer Treatment Centers of America, this group is in many states.  If your insurance will allow, or you afford it,  go to the best, at least try to go to a teaching hospital/clinic or a breast clinic. If you are like most of us, you can do all the preliminary stuff with your insurance, then, call one of the majors and ask them the cost.  Then collect original mammograms. original slides and all reports, and send them on for a second or, if something is strange, even 2 places, and if everyone agrees with diagnosis, treatment, etc.  You are good to go at home.  This second opinion is usually arounf $500, well worth it.   But remember, the cure rate for BC is 80%, so do not go nuts. Gentle hugs, Shirlann (13 years post treatment)
Posts.Title: My wife just got diagnosed, where to go? mywifemylife mywifemylife

Posts.Content: Sep 8, 2008 09:27PM Shirlann wrote: Well the best news is that about 80% of us recover completely.  Much better stats than heart disease, which is the leading killer of women.  I would suggest getting Dr. Susan Love's Breast Book, don't read the last chapters, they will only scare you and you wont' need them.  I am 10 years post treatment and fine.  In my bible study, when I blubberingly told them I had breast cancer, 3 women piped up, one was 22 years post double mast, one was 17 years post treatment and the last one was 11 years post treatment.  They are all just fine to this day.  I was floored.  But people just don't talk about it.  I met a lady at the dog park and she had BC in 1985 and sometimes forgets which side it was on.  My mom's best friend just died of old age, 50 years post double mastectomy, she was a contract bridge player and took care of herself alone in her own house until the very end. I started with a large group of women, kinda like we all do.  They have all moved on, they were younger with jobs and families.  So when you read the threads, just know that there are literally thousands of women out there who have been through treatment and are just fine. Don't get me wrong.  We were all scared half silly.  It is a long, ugly process, seems like slow motion sometimes.  A lot of the women use anti-depressives during this time and then slowly get off them when you get your confidence in your body back and get back on your feet.  It is a shock, it was to all of us. I also took a small tape recorder with me to all the appts. and procedures, then I didn't have to try and remember all the stuff they throw at you.  My mind was not doing too well in the first place and here I was, expected to take this all in, digest it, and make sense of it and try to make decisions. Sounds like you have done a very good job of this.  Your decision do a hyster is a good one.  I had a lumpectomy and radiation.  It went very well for me, I did not burn.  Some girls do, it is hard to predict.  Fumi, our dear sister from Japan, lived all alone, kept working and did chemo.  So did our Sue, from Wales, she is a Subway Manager with two boys at home.  She often worked 10 to 12 hour days.  So this is all doable.  Some people, as you will read, have hard times, some don't have a lot of trouble.  But just remember, not too many post."I had treatment, it wasn't too bad, and now I am fine".  But this is a common experience.  So stay off the net, except for here, of course, where your sisters will always help you and you can yell and cry, and rage all you want, we know just how you feel.  Unlike the people you tell who have not walked this walk. So you should do very well, expect this, Gentle hugs, Shirlann
Posts.Title: joining the club katesmom Shirlann

Posts.Content: Oct 2, 2008 12:22AM Shirlann wrote: Fist of all, no, one cm is not big.  We have had 12cm women do just fine.  Size is one issue, but there are many others.  Try your best not to get ahead of yourself.  Of course you are worried, having fought this devil before, but still, 80% of "thingys" in our breasts are benign. Even if the very worst happens, and you do have BC, about 80% of us recover very well.  And go on with our lives.  I myself, am 10 years post treatment and doing fine. So try to lay this down until you know something.  This is hard to do, but try very hard, to stay focused on the fact that miserable as this all is, you will be so happy when they say, "benign". Gentle hugs, Shirlann

Posts.Title: a word of encouragement sylvie pod1257

Posts.Content: Sep 27, 2008 03:47AM Shirlann wrote: Hi jvale, well there is no question you need to see a doctor as soon as you can.  Especially with a family history of BC.  Also, the symptoms, of course, can be many things, but only a doc can tell with testing. If you can, see a breast specialist or go to a breast clinic.  They are best equipped for diagnosing things.  80% of these "thingys" that are in our breasts are benign, but that still leaves 20%.  If found early, breast cancer is curable, the longer you wait, the worse the odds, in most cases. So honey, get thee to a doc ASAP, and find out what is going on. We are all here for you, if you need any advice or help. Gentle hugs, Shirlann
Posts.Title: found lump in underarm jvale77 Shirlann

Posts.Content: Feb 11, 2011 09:07PM Shirlann wrote: Hi honey, get Dr. Susan Love's  Breast Book, it will answer so many questions. ER and PR negative means your cancer is "Estrogen and Progesteron Negstive" in other words, the tumor is not driven by either progesteron or estrogen.  This has good and bad sides.  I am a "TRI NEG" (this is what we call ourselves).  This type of cancer is more aggressive than some, but on the good side, when you get to 2 or three years out of treatment, this cancer rarely re-occurs. There is a whole thread of women who are tri-negs.  When I was diagnosed 12 years ago, no one knew much about it, and just said, hmmmmm, now more info has been gathered so the providers are better informed for you. I had a lumpectomy and rads, my tumor was small. Come often and we will all help you. Gentle hugs, Shirlann

They see something, but not enough to go nuts over, and they want to see you sooner rather than at your regular time, of course this is scary, but I think they are just being prudently cautious. If you just can't handle the time frame, ask to come back in 3 months.  That will help. Gentle hugs, Shirlann
Posts.Title: Not sure what this means.... connorsmommy Nanstoys

Posts.Content: Jan 8, 2009 09:47AM Shirlann wrote: Hi honey, welcome to the club.  You need to know that about 80% of us recover from this completely and almost 100% if the cancer is found early, pretty good odds, a whole lot better than heart disease. So try not to get to jumpy.  Still a no fun year ahead of you.   If you want a second opinion, the cheapest way is to call a super cancer center, like Sloan-Kettering in New York, Dana Farber in Baltimore, or is that Johns Hopkins?  Anyway, ask what it costs to re-do your slides.  Then, you get your slides, original mammo's and ship the whole lot off for about $500 and you get a pathologist who does ONLY breast cancer and will give you a new report and a new diagnosis and a treatment recommendation.  Ask how much, usually around $500.  Some women have done this more than once.  This way, if everyone agrees, you are good to go. Gentle hugs, Shirlann
Posts.Title: newbie here skippyrcis whippetmom

Posts.Content: Jul 15, 2008 08:19PM Shirlann wrote: If possible, both of you young ones need to try your best to get genetic screening.  This does not solve all the problems, but I would get with a geneticist and address this problem, now, while you are young. It is so hard to be this young and have to worry like this.  I am so sorry.  But there are a couple of tests, BRCA gene being one, that you can check on, and ask the practitioner what should you do? This is a grey area of breast issues, and needs to be more carefully addressed.  Certainly, with close relatives this young with BC, do not ignore this or be pushed off. Gentle hugs, Shirlann
Posts.Title: Worried campe pennzer

Posts.Content: Sep 13, 2008 11:06PM - edited Sep 13, 2008 11:07PM by Shirlann Oh Joy, honey, I wish I could just gather you in my arms and give you a giant hug.  It is so hard to have multiple health issues, we have had other women with Lupus, and one with MS and a few other things.  But the idea that cancer is the cause of all these things is silly, and you must know that. It does not work that way, usually.  It takes time.  So do your best to take one day at a time, one step at a time.  This can still have an acceptable outcome.  About 80% of us get well, and that is a big number. Anger is perfectly okay on this site.  I can top your sister's response, I told my ONLY sibling, and she said and I quote, "Well, that is what you get for having all those mammograms!".  Then I didn't hear from her for weeks.  Now, I sure felt beloved.  Some of our women, their siblings quit their jobs to care for them, people run around for them, I had just my wonderful husband, so I sure do understand all the pain,  Honey, you have been handed TOO DAMN MUCH for any one person to deal with. But  your back is not cancer and your bladder is not cancer.  But trust me, we all thought this about every ache and pain, in fact, my back hurts right now! So keep posting, we will help you all we can, and I really don't want to tell you this, but usually, you have to wait for the pathology report a week or so, to stage the cancer, check the lymph nodes, and on and on and on. This is no fun, but you are a sister now, and you are in our club, and we are very close to our sisters.  We will always be here for you. Gentle hugs, Shirlann

Posts.Content: Dec 26, 2007 06:57PM Shirlann wrote: Honey, the good news is, most of us, about 90% , will recover and be just fine.  The bad news is, as with most cancers, there is no cut and dried "you are cured" time frame with most cancers. It is surely true that the longer you go without any new problems, the less likely you are to have any more problems.  But if this is keeping you upset, try some anti-deps for a time, until you get your confidence in your body back, and then you can slllowlly get off them. This helps immensely since this is really a waiting game, and if you are like most of us, this is very hard to deal with.  So get some chemical help. Gentle hugs, Shirlann

Posts.Content: Aug 17, 2008 08:38PM Shirlann wrote: Okay, this is the story.  Obviously, no one treating your mom is sure at this time.  If you have breast cancer that spreads to other organs, either lungs, liver or bones and sometimes brain, this is called metastases.  This is much more serious than just a single, one spot breast cancer.  This is Stage IV, which is survivable, but only up to a point. Now, you don't know yet, so don't jump to any conclusions.  Wait and see.  Things may be not so bad.  My sister constantly has "scary results" from lung/chest x-rays and all it is is old bronchitis scars from her youth.  So try to stay calm until you know more. So the story is, when the breast cancer speads to other organs, it is still breast cancer, but it has spread.  So this is the part that is confusing you.  Versus two separate cancers.  They can tell this under a microscope. If they think they might be able to cure her with a lung lobe removal, then that might be the way to go.  If it is just a delaying action, you need to know that, too.  this is assuming the lung thing is anything at all.  I would get Dr. Susan Love's Breast Book, just so you can stay ahead on the "lingo".  It is so confusing at first.  Also, I took a small tape recorder with me so I did not have to take notes or try to remember. Let's hope that all this is something benign.  Stay at that point until you know more. Gentle hugs, Shirlann
Posts.Title: Where to go from here? chipdog3 chipdog3

Posts.Content: Aug 28, 2008 06:40AM - edited Aug 28, 2008 06:42AM by Shirlann Hi honey, 80% of these "thingys" are nothing, so try to keep that in mind while you wait.  If anything suspicious is found, there are things you can do to be on top of this thing. If and believe me, this is a very big if, you do have cancer, you can most likely safely have it out locally, it is not rocket science, the big concern, is clean margins.  Then, get your original slides, your mammograms, and call Sloan-Kettering, Dana Farber, Mayo Clinic, Johns Hopkins, any one of the really big, famous cancer centers.  Ask them how much and an address to send your stuff to, and they will do a new pathology report and a recommendation for treatment.  It is usually around $500.  Then, Fed-Ex the whole lot to them and you will have the best pathologist in the world doing your slides.  They will send you a new pathology report and a new recommendation for treatment, if this all agress with your local people, you are good to go. this is jumping WAAAY ahead, but I want to ease your mind about being in a small community. I sent my things to UCLA, and when they agreed with my local team, I was at ease.  So almost certainly you won't need this info, still, it is good to know you are not out of reach of the best medical care for cancer in the world, while living on your lovely island. Gentle hugs, Shirlann

Posts.Content: Sep 2, 2008 04:31AM - edited Sep 2, 2008 05:39AM by Shirlann Hi again Nancy, the east coast had a lot of chemical crap years ago and probably still.  So you have a legitimate worry.  And the contamination could be many miles away, nicely hidden in the underground aquifers most cities use for their water. So keep on checking, then start a class action suit, if you can find the perpetrators.  The hard part, of course, is getting any info on who was responsible when it could have been years ago.  But not necessarily, so well worth the effort to check. You might need to find out where your water comes from.  This is not the only source of contaminents, for sure, but the easiest one to track.  You can also take your tap water and have it independently analyzed at a lab, checking specifically for carcinogens, then work backwards to see who "dumped" whatever is found (if anything, it could be the air, the dirt, etc.). Good luck, dear friend, Shirlann

Posts.Content: Jan 19, 2008 02:06PM Shirlann wrote: Okay, I am going to jump in here with what I think you need to do.  We here in California have to go to our Primary for referrals for anything they can't handle too, and I know how annoying this can be. They are not too concerned because I think they feel you are too young to have anything very serious.  This may be true, but you need to be aware of a very unusual breast cancer called Inflammatory Breast Cancer.  It presents with wierd symptoms and cannot be diagnosed, only with a biopsy.  It would be one in a million if this is what you have, partly because of the time frame.  You have been trying to get help with this for ages, and I think IBC would be giving you a lot more trouble. However, leaving no stone unturned, even an unlikely one, I think you need to get a biopsy.  I don't like the nipple inverting.  This is another major symptom. As I said, the chances that this is IBC are remote.  But many doctors have never even seen it, so if you don't bring this up, and get someone to check you for this, nothing will be done.  In any case, you have the right to get whatever this is diagnosed.  It is not normal, it is not likely an infection because of the anti-biotic use with no results.  They need to look harder and you need to push them.  I would take this page of responses with you.  And Google IBC, too.  Then you can say to them, I want to be checked for this. They are just hoping you will go away, we have the same problem here. Keep posting, let us know what happens. Gentle hugs, Shirlann

Posts.Content: Oct 18, 2007 03:47AM Shirlann wrote: I don't want to be the tennis shoe in the punch bowl, but double masts do not FOR SURE mean no more cancer. You can get a recurrence in the chest wall, or in the scar, etc. It is impossible to completely remove all the breast tissue on anyone, it runs up your arm in the front and on the side of the breast. So the decision to do a double mast should be made for the right reasons. One reason, multi-focal breast cancer, or, lumps in several places in the breast, or gals with extremely dense breasts for whom mammos are not a great screening tool. Strong family history of BC. Lumps in both breasts. There is a slight percentage advantage to a double mast and you often avoid radiation. And that is sure a good thing. So I am not opposed to a double mast, just do your research and be sure you understand everything. Gentle hugs, Shirlann Gentle hugs, Shirlann
