Posts.Title: Melt down at Dr office cemjo3 Naomi

Posts.Content: Sep 11, 2007 01:10PM Shirlann wrote: Honey, you might need some chemical help.  Ask for Ativan or Xanax (I read my posts and I am starting to sound like a drug pusher!) so you don't have to go to hell and back with these procedures.  It just takes the edge off and will let you heal faster and get well quicker.  Pain and fear are not what we want here, if it can be helped. It also helps to know other than the nipple/aerola area, breasts do not have many nerves.  My tech was doing the needle thingy and I was sitting in the sonar spot, and he just said, "Oh heck, I am just going for it".  Did not hurt at all.  He taped a paper cup over the needle and my hubby drove me to the out-patient clinic.  Had a lot of fun with that place, I did not want any blood, of any kind, and kinda made them mad.  So they grudgingly put a "no blood" strap on my wrist.  Then, I kid you not, they gave me a paper to sign that was permission for them to do a blood test if there was an accidental stick. (HIV, I think).  I thought this was funny, so I said, "Well, I don't want your blood and it appears you don't want mine!".  I thought it was hilarious, but they just grumbled. Then I walked into the operating room, laid down on the "bed", no place for my arms, I was glad when they pulled out two boards and my arms went there.  It took the surgeon only about 3 Novacaine sticks, he was done in 30 minutes, I got up, walked to the sorta recovery area and after about an hour, went out to lunch with my hubby.  For me, it was nothing.  I have had many worse experiences in a dentist's office.  So we are all very different, and our cancers, of course are different, in different places, different sizes, etc.  But this is not a bad surgery.  Remember you don't need to pee, poop, eat or walk with your breast.  The underarm thingy was a lot worse. Keep posting, you are with a great sisterhood. Gentle hugs, Shirlann

Posts.Title: just found out and really need help nana_of_3 Shirlann

Posts.Content: Jun 25, 2008 02:51PM Shirlann wrote: Okay, Lisa, let's assume the very worst that you are worried about.  You have breast cancer.  Well, I am here to tell you that I swear 1/3 of the female population has it or has had it, or will get it.  I am 9 & 1/2 post treatment and my many friends, I made, when I joined this board are alive and well and have moved on with life.  Remember, lymph nodes are designed to stop things from moving on through your body, so having positive nodes is not ideal, but is not that bad.  We had a woman with 27 out of 27 nodes positive 17 YEARS AGO!  She is just fine.  My mom's best friend recently died of old age, living alone by choice, a contract bridge player and 42 YEARS POST DOUBLE MASTECTOMY.  I met a lady at the dog park and she had BC in 1985 and told me she often forgets which side it was on. You are kinda thinking 1935 times.  Back then, things were very different.  Today, with the newer treatments, 90% of us will recover.  So stop the plans for your eulogy and answer your phone. You are not going to die.  A very few of us die.  It is a long, hard, nasty journey, but on this site we have women who will help you every inch of the way. I have never met such kind, well informed, lovely women that will leap to your aid and answer questions and let you scream and yell all you want.  This is a venting forum, in a way.  You can be yourself with your sisters. You have not been diagnosed, but it seems you might be.  But come back here and let us know what your path report says, and in a couple of hours you will have women with the exact same diagnosis on here to help you, explain, and by the way, most of them are doing very well. I don't mean to sound mean, but you will get well, you will not die, you will make friends that will fill your life with comfort and that is assuming the news is BC. Gentle hugs, Shirlann

Posts.Content: Nov 6, 2007 08:05PM - edited Nov 6, 2007 08:09PM by Shirlann Hi Barbara, are you having a mast?  Or are you able to have a lumpectomy?  I can't get over your wanting things faster.  Get this, the bunch I was with found a lump and it was two years before they agreed to further testing.  (We did a mammo every 6 months).  Then, back to back, comsuming 3 whole months, I had a stereotactic, a compression, an ultrasound, a couple of other things I have forgotten, and FINALLY they did a biopsy.  Then, they thought I had Lymphoma! Well, they sent my slides to White Plains, NY to a specialist and I had Medullary BC, which is a small sub-type.  By now, I am an OLD WOMAN, and I started out young,  haha.  Sheesh, I was so mad by then, as soon as my lumpectomy and radiation were over, I got out of that health plan, pronto!  It seems to me you are moving along at lightening speed, compared to my snail pace.  haha On a couple of Internet sites they have bras with one side "ready-made"  also bathing suits with one side "ready made".  This might be something you could think about.  Anyway, love, keep us posted. Shirlann
Posts.Title: Why am I not upset? Barbara1 Mary-Lou

Posts.Content: Dec 12, 2007 06:08PM - edited Dec 12, 2007 06:09PM by Shirlann Hi Barbara, I have been lurking and reading your posts, and the other girls, laughed and cried with all of you, didn't have too much to offer, but now, I do! I am a Triple Negative, that means your breast cancer is not estrogen nor progesterone driven, hence the PR-/ER-, then the Her2neu, is also negative, and that is a good thing. What it means is that we don't benefit from Tamoxifen or Femara, newer drugs that are a real wonder for ER and PR positive gals, they don't do us much good.  BUT on the bright side, and who knows why, we have more aggressive tumors, recurrence, metastasis, but after 2 or 3 years, our recurrence rate almost drops to nothing, while the "normal" gals gradually taper off.  AAACKK, too much info sometimes. But I so admire your strength and courage, your faith and all the faith and love of the women on this thread.  I just wanted to stick in my little bit of info.  (PS:  I am 9 years post treatment) Gentle hugs, Shirlann

Posts.Content: Aug 30, 2008 03:36PM Shirlann wrote: Hi Rocky and welcome.  I am curious, why are they sure it is a metatastic lymph node?  I would head for a cancer clinic or a breast cancer specialist and get a 2nd opinion.  This is a little strange.  So I would like another person to look, if it were me.  This is pretty easy to do, you call Sloan-Kettering, Johns Hopkins, or Dana Farber, or any of the top cancer centers and ask them the cost of a new pathology report and a recommendation for treatment.  Then, if this is all okay, you collect your original slides, original mammos, copies of your records and FedEx the whole lot to the facility you have chosen.  This is relatively inexpensive, sometimes insurance will pay, sometimes not.  But it is around $500.  Money well spent when you have something that is a little different. Husbands are usually pretty helpless.  They are the protectors of the family, since caveman days, and they cannot "fix" this problem.  Some get mean, some get dismissive, "Oh you'll be fine".  It is hard for them because they are responsible (not really, but this is their mind set). I hope all goes well, keep posting. Gentle hugs, Slirlann

Posts.Content: Sep 6, 2008 07:03PM - edited Sep 6, 2008 07:08PM by Shirlann Hi and welcome, here's hoping your stay with us will be very short!  The thing to know is that 80% of these "thingys" that are felt are benign.  It could be a cycle cyst, or a fibroadenoma or many other things besides breast cancer. Most breast cancers, when large enough to be found by any means, are 8 to 10 years old.  So even if this is something, (and it most likely isn't) this time to check yourself out is no problem. My breasts also point at the floor, I have had 3 children and lost and gained weight like mad for years, and both of mine look at the floor too.  I think the weight gain, then losing it is key for this, in any case, to my knowledge, this "pointing direction" has absolutely nothing to do with BC. One of the big issues is family history, so if your mom is around, or aunts, check and see if anybody has had breast cancer, since they will ask you this at your appt. STOP WORRYING, it would be very unlikely if this is anything at all.  Some of our women have been going in for look-sees of lumps for years and years.  Some women just grow them, we don't know why. Come back and let us know what you hear, and I bet it is good news. Gentle hugs, Shirlann
Posts.Title: Super scared!!! lynnlife spar2

Posts.Content: Jan 8, 2008 09:28PM - edited Jan 8, 2008 09:31PM by Shirlann Oh I guess so, but I am 9 years post treatment and doing fine and I had Triple Negative cancer. You should do just fine. This ER/PR negative just means we don't usually take Tamoxifen. Way back when I was diagnosed, I was glad. But no one knew much about Triple Negs back then. Think of it this way, there are 20 arrows in your quiver to fight this thing, only one is missing, I bet you will never even miss it. The GOOD NEWS is, we have a slightly more aggressive cancer, but if we get by 2 to 3 years, our recurrence rate drops to almost nothing. While the other types just continue on a normal downward trip. So that is great. Now, the hard part, holding your breath for 2 years. Nawwww, just kidding. Since 90% of us recover, Triple Negs and all, you have an excellent chance of being completely back to normal, most of us are or will be. When I started posting on this site 5 years ago I met a giant group of wonderful gals. Well, now, most are off living their old lives, all doing just fine. So don't worry, what is is. Can't change it, so we just take one day at a time. Gentle hugs, Shirlann

Posts.Title: post major duct excision problems misheley misheley

Posts.Content: Sep 4, 2008 08:33PM Shirlann wrote: First of all, welcome to this board.  You are a sister here and please come and post often.  I agree 100% with your surgeon, I had a stereotactic that did not hit the "spot" and that error caused another delay.  So I say, the only good lump is in a jar.  Go for it.  It is not that bad.  You do not eat, pee, poop, laugh, sit or walk with your breasts, if you have a little surgery there, there isn't a better spot.  I had a small tumor, near the surface, and just had lidocaine, and he took it out.  I waited a few hours and went out to lunch with my hubby. Hardly any pain for me (others, of course, have different experiences) because there are very few nerves in the breast.   Some surgeons prefer a general anesthetic, that, of course, is their choice.  But when he is done, you will have a complete pathology report to see and the "thingy" will be GONE.  That is great, I wish my group had done this in the first place. Most breast cancers, not all, but most, have been in our bodies for 8 to 12 years.  So the time is not an issue.  If he is going to do the node look see at the same time, you are really lucky, you only have to screw up your courage once.  Mine took about 6 procedures to get where you will be in only one procedure. So hang in there, you are not being filled with cancer (we all thought this) and you will most likely be just fine, and get your life back.  I am 10 years post treatment and just got back from a trip 1300 miles up the Amazon.  LIfe is good again.  Around 80% of us recover fully and are well.  A lot better statistics than heart patient diagnosis. Gentle hugs, Shirlann

If you are a reader, get Dr. Susan Love's Breast Book, and read only the first part.  This book will explain a lot of terms and things that are usually done.  But don't read the later chapters because you won't need them and they will scare you. So hang in there, things should be fine.  It is a nasty, long journey, but it can be done. Gentle hugs, Shirlann

Posts.Content: Jun 19, 2008 01:38PM Shirlann wrote: Hi, absolutely, some of our women get 2 second opinions.  It is really quite easy and usually not too expensive.  What you do is:  Call your facilities:  Ask to have original slides, original mammo's, and copies of your records.  Then, call Sloan-Kettering, Dana Farber, Mayo Clinic, UCLA, any one of the top cancer centers.  Ask them how much for a new pathology report and a treatment recommendation.  Then, send the whole lot to them, they will re-do your pathology, give you a new report and recommend treatment. I did this at UCLA, back then, 9 years ago, it was only $125.  But who knows now?  Anyway, they don't need you, just your stuff. If this new report from a pathologist who usually does nothing but breast slides, agrees with the one you got originally, you are good to go.  If there is a difference of opinion, then you need to deal with that.  Either send your stuff someplace else, or change docs/oncs. It really is quite easy. If you want more info, just PM me. Hugs, Shirlann

Posts.Content: Oct 28, 2007 07:42PM - edited Oct 28, 2007 07:44PM by Shirlann No, I didn't lose my faith. God does not guarantee no problems, just the peace of his presence in our lives to enable us to deal with it. But don't feel bad about doubting, as one of our posters said, I don't think there is a single one of us who has not doubted. I remember one Sunday at Mass our dear priest grabbed the sides of the lectern, leaned over and said, "I have doubts too. I don't have all the answers. I am just like you all, on a journey, that has good days and bad days. But God will see us through, with his son Jesus, we can do it" I have never forgotten those words. And I often question, this is fine, God does not expect no questions, that is human, and he gave us free will, so there will always be questions. This is okay and does not mean you are bad, a disbeliever, evil, or anything like that. This just means you are human. Gentle hugs, Shirlann

Posts.Content: Aug 22, 2008 02:01PM Shirlann wrote: Well, there certainly are cases that have side effects.  No question.  But what the docs/oncs have to weigh, is the danger of a serious side effect worth not doing treatment and dying of breast cancer?  What a dilemma!  Your mom is here, and that is a victory, for sure.  No, in my limited experience, taking off from treatment is not an enormous risk.  Many women have to stop for low white counts or low red counts, others who have flu or bad colds, etc.  So while everyone wants to stay the course, I notice we quite easily skip the weekends for radiation, because no one wants to work on their days off, so if it was that critical, I would think they would. Cancer NORMALLY does not spread like that.  With some few exceptions, of course.  It is typical for a year or two to go by, with treatment finished, then something might happen.  I am surely not a doctor or an oncologist.  So this is just conjecture and what I have observed on this board, but I would not worry about this delay. Hugs, Shirlann

Posts.Content: Aug 8, 2008 07:22PM - edited Aug 8, 2008 07:24PM by Shirlann Personally, the work for me was helpful.  I was distracted and busy, and I could not think of two things at once.  It helped me.  Now, the germs.  If you get sick, well, you get sick.  But I think the working is well worth the risk.  All we can do is speak from our own experiences, and this was mine.  Be sure and get your flu shot, as that is something you definitely don't want this year. Oh, yes, I got home and just sat in my jammies until it was time to go to bed, don't plan ANYTHING for the evenings after rads.  Then, by morning, I was fine again.  Gentle hugs, Shirlann

Posts.Content: Nov 25, 2008 06:44PM Shirlann wrote: Well, yes, if you can.  It just makes sense to use all the things they are learning to stay in good health. And don't assume you will have a miserable time, even if you do get BC. (Boy, that is reaching for it), but I had a small cancer, went into an out-patient clinic, had it off with novocaine, then went home.  Can't even find the scar.  Then, I had radiation.  I worked through the whole thing.  6 days after I finished rads I went on a strenuous trip to Baja to see the whales.  I was 63, that was 10 years ago. I don't mean to sound like a Pollyanna, or presume that things would be the same for you.  But detection early is the key to an easier time with this.  And the BRCA gene test would give you a lot of information. So while this whole rigamarole is never any picnic, many of us have a lot easier time of it than some do.  The problem is, most "easy" cases, no one writes about.  That is one reason I stick around.  This is not the end of the world or the end of you.  With two sisters, you need to be vigilant, and I would gather all the info you can, and then stop worrying. This is not easy, but you can do this.  Just make up your mind that cancer (or the possiblity of it) will NOT rule your life. Just so you know that this is very survivable and very doable, if this is even necessary.  I have a sister who is 75 and won't even get a mammogram.  Dumb, if you ask me.  But this is her choice.  I personally would rather be on top and in control. So this is a decision you will have to make, but whatever you decide to do, you will not necessarily get breast cancer in any case. Gentle hugs, Shirlann

Posts.Content: Jul 23, 2008 05:30PM Shirlann wrote: Hi, I am 9 & 1/2 years post treatment and I had Costochondritis.  It got better, but it took about 2 years.  Once I knew what it was (thanks to Dr. Susan Love's Breast Book, not the rads doc) I was pretty much able to ignore it, and it did get better. BUT, now I have some pain still and the concensus is osteo-necrosis, or in english, dead bone.  They had a few ideas of how to treat it, but I don't really want any more anything and I am 73 and can do what I need to do so I decided, no more x-rays or surgery, and they don't know if it would help. Aren't even sure of the diagnosis. So very few people get this, and it does come on about 3 to 6 weeks AFTER finishing rads.  One way Dr. Love says to sorta diagnose it is to squeeze the area, pinch the skin, and if it hurts, it is Costochondritis.  I have truly never run into but one other woman who had long term problems like mine, so you should be fine after a time. Gentle hugs, Shirlann
Posts.Title: Costochondritis? Liz08 Ardychan

Posts.Content: Aug 23, 2008 02:14AM - edited Aug 23, 2008 02:15AM by Shirlann Well, if it is in the rib area, it is most likely Costochondritis, or, in english, inflammation of the meat between the ribs.  Hurts like the dickens.  And exercise stirs it up, although I doubt it would hurt it any.  Dr. Susan Love talks about this in her Breast Book.  One thing to do, according to her, is to pinch the spot, if it hurts like the dickens, it is usually Costochondritis.   I am not diagnosing you, you need to see a doc/onc, for sure, but this is likely what it is. Oh, I have a pemanent sore spot, I don't know what it is.  It has been suggested that it is osteo-necrosis, or dead bone.  Lovely thought.  But I am almost 10 years post treatment, I don't want anything else done, just glad to be alive.  But, as always, get it checked by a doc.  Hugs, Shirlann  PS:  Oh, it comes on a while AFTER rads are finished.

Posts.Content: Jan 17, 2013 06:58PM Shirlann wrote: Yes, after a good bit of time to heal, you can weight train.  The doc will know about your lymph nodes after the surgery.  If the cancer is small and no lymph nodes are involved, generally, a lumpectomy is enough.  Other scenarios take more thought.  Doing a mastectomy is NOT a positive that you will never worry again.  You can have a recurrence in the chest wall or in the scar.  It is impossible to get out ALL the breast tissue, it runs, up your arm and under your arm.  You have better odds with a mast, but don't do it if you don't have to.  Dr. Susan Love says in her book she would rather have breast tissue left to work on in case of recurrence instead of having to dig the cancer out of the chest wall.

Posts.Content: Jan 14, 2009 07:25PM Shirlann wrote: I hear you.  The easiest thing to do with Mayo is the same thing I suggested with the other places.  Call them, ask for prices, and they only need original slides and original mammograms in order to re-do the pathology.  If Mayo agrees with your providers, you are in good shape.  Normally, here, at least in California, (we are mostly in HMO's) they do not do an MRI without either a great health care insurance plan or strong indications.  We are in practically the same boat as you are in. As far as Tamoxifen, it is not genetic testing, it is testing to see if your wife's cancer is estrogen or progesteron driven.  This would show up on the pathology as ER, or PR + or -.  Some doctors like to give this drug (or its newer sister) whether you show up positive or not.  It is a drug that binds the estrogen to the drug and does not let it cause cancer as easily.  It is a good thing, but I am certain that it is available and used in Canada,  The only genetic testing I know of is for the BRCA Gene, and there is no medicine for that, it just indicates a double mast and possibly a hysterectomy is maybe a good idea. If I were you, I would get Dr. Susan Love's Breast Book and read it.  She is an advocate for women and what she tells you is very straight forward and easy to understand. They pushed me off with the "wait and see" too.  For 2 years.  Then, when something did show up, they thought I had Lymphoma, they then had to send my slides to White Plains, New York because no one here knew what I had, then in utter disgust, I went to UCLA.  I had a sub-type of breast cancer called Medullary, doesn't mean anything, but they did not know what it was. The only reason for an MRI, and it is done for some, is to see if the cancer has left the breast area and moved to other organs.  I sure didn't get one, and it was money constraints here, too, without any symptoms, they just don't do them here unless you are rich. It is very easy to get completely disgusted with health care here or in Canada.  I was furious.  But you are definitely doing the right thing, taking charge and learning on your own what is up. Get Dr. Love's book, so you will know so much more.  My husband and I wore one out and had to buy a second one.   Don't hesitate to come back with any questions or concerns.  We have some women on here that I swear are better than the oncologists. Gentle hugs, Shirlann

Posts.Content: Aug 6, 2008 08:27PM Shirlann wrote: Hi Kim, I am not sure myself why getting to be taken seriously is so hard.  When they must know what we risk by not checking out things, I am amazed at how cavalier the providers can be. So, you must press on and get an answer that not only makes sense, but is correct.  Your age is one reason they are so vague, since breast cancer is rare is such young women.  But trust me, it surely is not impossible.  It happens.  And you don't want to go undiagnosed until some jackass decides to take you seriously. You need to stay calm, they do not like us to be hysterical or mean.  Just don't give up.  I think a round of antibiotics was an excellent idea, since infection is a very good guess at this point.   However, if you can get an MRI, that is a better test than a mammo, which is only about 70% accurate and less accurate on young women with dense breasts.  So the 3 week wait is miserable, but if this is what it is, you can surely try to get it pushed up, like, ask them to call you if they get a cancellation.  This is a good call. Most of the time, pain is not a BC symptom.  But not always.  Some women do have pain.  This thing is so variable, almost nothing can be said for positive.  There is a very rare (highly unlikely) breast cancer called IBC, or, Inflammatory Breast Cancer, which can only be caught with a biopsy.  Most docs have never seen it.  And it presents with a rash, or tiny pimples, or an inverted nipple, itching, etc.  I don't want to scare you, but you need to know about this, just to remind them to be aware of this unusual type. Come back any time you get worried or have something happen or just to talk.  This site is full of kind, gentle, helpful women who will be with you till you leave with an "all clear", or stay with BC.  So come often, and be sure to let us know how things go. Gentle hugs, Shirlann

Posts.Content: Aug 7, 2008 03:23PM Shirlann wrote: Well, Beesie is a lot better at answers than I am, but my understanding is that younger women (before Menopause) have denser breasts.  Dense breasts make it more difficult to find things.  Especially with a mammogram.  MRI's will "light up", I think, with cancer.  So this is a better test for the younger women.  Usually, the radiologist report or your doc will tell you if you have unusually dense breasts.  It is also on the report.  Get copies of all these reports and start your own file, who knows where  you will be in 10 years?  I got all my reports and original mammo's and keep them myself. If you are worried, then don't stop until you are satisfied.   I will try to find Beesie. Hugs, Shirlann

Posts.Content: Sep 5, 2008 09:52AM Shirlann wrote: First of all welcome to this board of kind, helpful women. Then, as you know, our entire bodies have hundreds of lymph nodes.  They are everywhere, I guess except the brain. So, on the mammogram they saw a "tail" on a lymph node.  This in itself, should not be cause for alarm.  But because they are being super careful, they will note anything that is not usually seen on other mammograms.   So nothing too sinister at this point.  It sounds to me like your group has good people who are being very cautious.  So try not to worry and remember, lymph nodes are all over our bodies to keep things from moving on to other organs.  They are the sentinels of our parts.  This should not be of to much concern at this point. Since everything will scare you silly till this is resolved, just keep in mind that 80% of all "thingys" seen in the breast are benign. Gentle hugs, Shirlann

Posts.Content: Mar 23, 2008 06:42PM - edited Mar 23, 2008 06:43PM by Shirlann Hi sisters, I have been around for 5 years and a good percentage of women have some lymph node involvement. Most of these gals do just fine. Remember, the lymph node system is throughout our bodies. Their job is to stop nasty things, cancer, infection, etc., from moving on to other places. So your lymph nodes were doing their job. Period. Try not to read any more in this than that. As far as life changing forever, no, it hasn't. Believe it or not, you will get back your old life and your old happy outlook, it just takes a long time. Most of us suffer some form of Post Traumatic Stress Syndrome, so keep that in mind. I always suggest that newbies get a drug, Ativan, valium, or something like that for appointment days and treatment days. And for nights when you wake up at 3am and the squirrels of worry are running around the bedroom. Helps a great deal. And you need your sleep. So hang on, dear sisters, almost all of us will be just fine. Gentle hugs, Shirlann

Posts.Content: Oct 18, 2007 07:58AM Shirlann wrote: Hi dear, we cannot tell what is going on, you need to see a doctor and doctors have all the knowledge that you need to know what is happening. I sure do understand your worry with so many relatives with BC.  All the more reason to go immediately and have this checked out.  And be sure that you tell whoever is treating you that you have this many relatives that have been touched by this disease. Breast cancer today is very treatable and you should not be afraid to go to the doctor.  You need to have a baseline mammo, or, one that shows you at a young age and then, as you have them yearly, the radiologist will have a "First Mammo" to compare the later ones to. Also, with this high incidence, it would be very good to get checked for the BRCA gene.  It is not likely you have this genetic marker, but you should be tested. Try not to worry until you hear from a professional what it up.  But do go soon, no sense worrying for nothing. Gentle hugs, Shirlann
Posts.Title: Nipple Itch ylonda awb

Posts.Content: Nov 23, 2007 05:28PM Shirlann wrote: Hi Amy, first of all, we have many, many women with positive nodes that are doing just fine. Remember, the nodes are specifically designed to stop things from moving on into your body, and this is what they did. We recently had a gal with 21 positive nodes, she is doing just fine. I too am a triple negative, 9 years post treatment and just fine, so don't get all caught up in this thing. It is what it is, and while maybe not the best thing, us triples have one good thing, after 2 to 3 years our recurrence rate drops drastically, unlike some of the other cancer types. I would take a small tape recorder and then you don't have to take notes or try to remember. Too stressed right now to think straight. Also, I liked Dr. Susan Love's Breast Book, I wore one out. Just read as far as you need to, some of the later chapters are scary, so stay away from them, you won't need them. This is a long nasty journey and every one of us have been right where you are. Terrified. This is perfectly normal. But please know that 90% of us will recover, go on with our lives, and be just fine. All the women I started with on this site, have moved on with their lives. I am retired now, so I hang around, I have made so many good friends, and I think it is good to know and hear from someone who has been NED (No Evidence of Disease) for so long. My mother's best friend just died of old age, she had a double mastectomy 49 years ago. She lived alone till she died and was a contract bridge player. So get busy, get as educated as you can, know you are not alone. Come and post often, there are wonderful kind women on this site, and you will get all the help you need and before you know it, you will be helping others. Gentle hugs, Shirlann

Posts.Content: Sep 17, 2008 02:54PM Shirlann wrote: Hi honey, this does not sound like cancer, now.  But what seems to be of concern to the breast surgeon is the future.  So I myself would go with her advice.  You have a lovely family, and you need to be there to raise them. Men are wonderful, but clueless.  Not their fault.  This is completely something they know nothing about.   But definitely something needs to be done and it looks like it involves surgery.  There are not a lot of nerves in the breast and you do not eat, drink, walk, talk, pee, poop or laugh with your breasts.  This is not too bad a place for surgery.  And generally, it goes quite well, with little pain and quick healing. So I would go with what she suggests.  Sounds like excellent advice to me. We have had many women nurse from only one breast, this is easily done, if you have more children. This part of the whole journey will drive a saint crazy.  We all hated it, but good for you to pursue this, and not just let it slide, that is the easy thing to do. Your goal is to remain well.  Second goal, to look nice, but believe me, waaay second.  So ask her all these things and even get a plastic surgeon involved.  They can usually fix about anything, and the law in most states is they HAVE to return you to your original "look" as best as possible. We are all with you, and you have an 80% chance this is nothing but a troublesome milk duct. Gentle hugs, Shirlann

Posts.Content: Jan 8, 2008 03:04PM Shirlann wrote: Honey, try your best to get a biopsy.  Geez, they act like doing a biopsy is the same as a brain transplant.  Makes me kinda mad, they cannot diagnose ANYTHING until that tissue is under a microscope, and yet they constantly refuse biopsies.  I guess it is the cost.  But man, they stalled me around for two years.  So I am quite angry and I ASKED for a biopsy and the surgeon said, "Oh, its not cancer, it is smooth and cancer's are spikey".  Well I had Medullary Breast Cancer which is characterized by smooth edges.  One would think he would have known that!  So I would just be a pest until you get a biopsy and get that lump in a jar where it belongs. Posts.Title: back from the tests- not showing up! paris9 Shirlann

Posts.Content: Mar 14, 2008 01:41AM - edited Mar 14, 2008 01:43AM by Shirlann Honey, there is a group of nerves right in the middle of your sternum that is famous for "acting up" under stress.  Do you have anything to take?  Like Ativan, Valium or something like that?  It would be a good diagnostic tool.  If it goes away, then it is that nerve center. Try to be sure you are taking a real good B Complex vitamin.  Won't cure anything, but sure does help in the nervous department. You are doing the right things, keep checking until you are satisfied with the answers.  But I suspect you are having an anxiety attack with the chest thing. Laughing Water, I have had anxiety issues my whole life, mainly throwing up and diarrhea, bet that is what you are dealing with.  Very common nervous reaction. No Fun. Gentle hugs, Shirlann

Posts.Content: Apr 28, 2008 10:26AM Shirlann wrote: Well, none of us are docs, and no one has a crystal ball, but I have been posting about 5 years and it is not very common.  I do believe that some forms of BC tend to return in the other breast more than other types.  But with DCIS, technically, you don't have cancer (invasive) in the first place.  You are in no danger of dying with this diagnosis. So while I would be super vigilant, as I am sure you will, I would try to put this whole thing in a shoe box on the top shelf of your closet.  Live your life and try not to dwell on "might be's". Gentle hugs, Shirlann

Posts.Content: Oct 21, 2008 05:46PM Shirlann wrote: Well what he is saying is that with the dense breasts that younger women usually have, mammograms are not that good. An MRI is a much better test.  This is not telling you that anything is wrong.  Most "thingys" found in the breasts of women as young as you are benign.  About 80%, and that is most of them. So try not to worry until you need to.  I am sure it is nothing but one of the many things women grow in their breasts that are not cancer.  And no, no one can truly tell you that you have cancer without the tissue under a microscope, but that is getting way ahead of yourself.  Take one baby step at a time and try not to get all upset.  Sounds like you have a very good provider who is just looking out for you very carefully. Gentle hugs, Shirlann

Posts.Content: Dec 2, 2008 08:43AM Shirlann wrote: Hi all, the only thing we truly have to go on is statistics.  They overwhelmingly recommend rads for certain situations and most of us do just fine with them.  I am 10 years post rads and fine.  No repercussions at all. If you do a lot of reading, and remember when they had NOTHING to treat this disease with, it becomes clear that while we all have choices, it is best to go with the treatments that have been tested for 30 years on literally thousands of women world-wide, and are known to work. So you always have a choice, just make this choice for the right reasons. Gentle hugs, Shirlann

Posts.Content: Nov 30, 2007 07:14AM - edited Nov 30, 2007 07:15AM by Shirlann Hi dear, I had a lumpectomy with just a local. I chatted throught the whole thing, waited in a little room for an hour and went out to lunch with my hubby. It was really nothing, my tumor was small. Now, if the area they want to get at is deep, or in a difficult spot, sometimes they need to do a general anesthetic. But I am like you, I HATE generals, so try for the local. Unless the area is difficult, or deep, you should be able to go to work the next day, I did. So it kinda depends on how much work they do. I don't think it would be a good idea to try to go to work with a general, they make me too sick. Be sure and let us know how things come out. Hugs, Shirlann

Posts.Content: Sep 12, 2007 03:04PM Shirlann wrote: Well, don't worry too much about being really knocked out, you will be anxious (as we all were) and that will keep you plenty concious.  So I would take one the night before, one when you wake up and see how it goes. You won't fall over, and your body does get a little used to drugs, so you will be less sleepy over time and just less stressed.  Then, when all this junk is over, you can stop the stuff. I guess what gets us all so upset is the length of time all this horsing around takes.  We are so used to going in, getting a script, taking it for a few days, and "voila" all well.  Cancer is very curable, but takes months.  But I remember my Grandma talking about her youth, and people would be in bed for 3 months with a bad case of pneumonia, we are spoiled, and expect to get well now. So keep posting, we will all help you as the other gals helped us, and you will be just fine and well soon. Gentle hugs, Shirlann

Posts.Title: Decoding help needed oldlady ICanDoThis

Posts.Content: Sep 16, 2008 02:17PM - edited Sep 16, 2008 02:18PM by Shirlann Hi honey, you NEVER look like an idiot taking proper care of your body, it is your only one.  DO NOT be intimidated by anyone. You need to go to a breast specialist, to have the BRCA test done, if you have not already done this. Mammograms are a huge blessing, but their error rate, especially in younger women with dense breasts, is around 30%, so there goes that comfort.   Get thee to a breast specialist, if this is at all possible, they are soooo much better at this than regular doctors.  You will be amazed. It is most likely nothing, but they pushed me off (my own fault) for 2 years because the surgeon said, "Oh it is not cancer, the lump is smooth, see?, and cancer lumps are spikey".  Well, when I finally got diagnosed I had a small sub-type of breast cancer called Medullary, which is characterized by "smooth edges".  I would not stop here with your family history. Gentle hugs, Shirlann

Posts.Content: Dec 30, 2007 12:49AM Shirlann wrote: Hi, I had a lumpectomy and had it on a Friday, then went back to work on Monday.  Very few nerves in the breast.  Of course, this depends on a few things.  I had a local, not a general, a small tumor not too far from the surface. I also worked through rads.  I had my zap about 4pm then went home and did very little.  By morning, I was fine again.  I was 63. Best of luck.  Hugs, Shirlann
Posts.Title: Recovery time heimbca Shirlann

Posts.Content: Dec 31, 2007 01:59AM - edited Dec 31, 2007 02:00AM by Shirlann I have a very slow recovery time with a general. But some surgeons want them, and if they do, not too much you can do about it. I had an axillary dissection (too long ago for sentinel node technique) and that was much worse to recover from as I had to have a general. But that was 9 years ago. I am 72 now. People range all over the place with radiation. Of course, and the rad onc will deny this, we have a slight form of radiation sickness. So the fatigue is that. But if you mention this, they go nuts. haha, who knows why? They must have read all the books from Hiroshima and Nagasaki that I did. Funny, huh. But my trick was I did NOTHING, and I mean NOTHING when I got home from my zap and by morning, I was just fine. Didn't burn, either. I know I was lucky. Gentle hugs, Shirlann

Posts.Content: May 12, 2008 07:40PM Shirlann wrote: Hi Dawn, you do understand that DCIS, in and of itself, is not life-threatening? You are in no danger with this diagnosis. So that is why they are suggesting a lumpectomy. Now, can anyone predict the future? No. And so this is why the docs/oncs/surgeons want you to make the decision, then if something goes wrong, they are not to blame. I had a lumpectomy with rads for my cancer 9 years ago, I am fine. But this is a complicated decision. Read and learn, be aware that having your sister diagnosed too is a bit ominous for the future. I would get Dr. Susan Love's Breast Book, read only as far as you need to, the later chapters might scare you and you won't need them. This helps you to decide. Information is power. Gentle hugs, Shirlann

Posts.Content: Dec 21, 2007 08:14PM Shirlann wrote: Honey, this is not bad at all.  It is no fun, surgery never is, but remember, you do not eat, pee, poop or smile from your breast.  You do not lift anything, sit on it or need it to walk.  This sounds stupid, but it makes getting better SO SO much easier.  Your breast will just sit there, minding its own business, (saying, "Don't roll over on me!), but that is all. I was surprised with the drains (no one told me), but I just pinned them to an old ratty bra, and went to work.  Now, they have bras with little pockets for the drains!  My oh my, what next? Of course, all my stuff is ancient history now, 9 years ago.  So I don't know what all the "new" stuff is about. But I got over this part quick, I think most of us do.  The most painful thing seems to be the gals who get the masts with the expanders?  Just seems that way, reading posts.  So you are wise to just wait and see how you feel later on. Hang in there, sweetie. Gentle hugs, Shirlann

Posts.Content: Aug 10, 2008 07:16PM Shirlann wrote: First of all, don't be scared.  Finding something at this early stage almost guarantees a cure, even if it is something.  But remember, mammo's only diagnose about 70% of breast cancers.  If you are still concerned about the hard area, just go back and say just that, "I want this seen under a microscope, since this is the only way to positively diagnose anything".  I think you will get results. Don't be to upset by the delay, most BC's when large enough to be found by any means, are 8 to 12 years old, so time to heal the breast is reasonable.  Kudos to all of you to pursue this until you are completely satisfied with the answers. Posts.Content: Aug 10, 2008 08:40PM Shirlann wrote: Well the old hospital joke goes like this:  "When 3 radiologists agree, throw everything out and start over".  The battles that go on that we never hear about or see are legendary.  Medicine is an art, not a science.  xrays are great on bones, just so so with soft tissue.  Disagree??  Oh yeah, they sometimes come to blows.  So much of medicine is in a kinda grey area.  One doc will think one thing and another one thinks the exact opposite.  It is kinda unnerving.  But that is the way it is.  I would go with the concerned surgeon, he has a lot more training and experience than the radiologist does. Hugs, Shirlann

Posts.Content: Oct 7, 2008 05:48PM Shirlann wrote: Hi, generally what is happening is hormonal changes.  You might watch your calendar and see if the pain comes and goes around your period.  This is fairly common.  Cancer would rarely occur in both breasts at once. Having said that, it is always a good idea to take your concerns to a doctor.  They have the training, the experience and the knowledge to know what is happening. So we are very happy you came to talk, but none of us can really give you a for certain answer.  Only a doctor. Gentle hugs, Shirlann

Posts.Content: Jun 11, 2008 06:44PM Shirlann wrote: Hi Toni, trust me, we have had a lot of nurses, and I think and they do to, that you actually know too much.  It truly is scarier when you have a lot of info you have personally observed. Dr. Susan Love in her book talks about an asian woman who came in with her two sons.  She examined the woman, found a huge tumor, explained all the options and diagnoses with the two boys, and was amazed that they relayed this info to the mom with just a few words in their language. Jump ahead, Dr. Love states she did not expect the woman to make it through with this large tumor and lymph node involvement, but treatment was done and they all left. 10 years later, here comes all three of them, mom and two sons, the mom smiling and well.  She truly felt that they told her practically nothing and that this helped her.  Just a cute story, but true. My oncologist is a very young man and I went to see him when I first started this journey.  I went several months later and saw a tiny newborn picture on his desk.  I asked him, "Is this little one yours?"  He said, "Yes, (then he sat down), he went on, "that birth was the worst thing I have ever been through in my life".  I had to laugh, and I told him, "You know too much".  He agreed. But you should be just fine and become a good friend we will all treasure. Gentle hugs, Shirlann

Posts.Content: Jun 1, 2011 02:46PM Shirlann wrote: Well, surgeons and oncs are not big fans of having both breasts involved or tiny tumors (they are hard to find).  They often will recommend masts with your wife's history.  How old she is can be an issue, younger women are at greater risk, pre-menopausal versus post-menopausal.  She can have immediate reconstruction, my daughter-in-law did, so that may help with the decision. If you went to 10 cancer centers, it would be unusual for them to agree, that is why cancer scares everyone silly. Remember, however, double masts will definitely improve her outcome, especially with dense breasts, but it is impossible to remove every last breast cell, it goes up her arm and under a ways too.  But you will eliminate the dense tissue issue.   You are at one of the best facilities in the world at Johns Hopkins, so that is excellent. Posts.Content: Jul 15, 2008 08:11PM - edited Jul 15, 2008 08:12PM by Shirlann Honey, do not be that worried.  It is always a rule with "multi-focal" BC that you have a mastectomy.  Just routine.  And also very common to use chemo first to shrink the tumors so your surgery is easier.  AND they get to try the chemo cocktail to be sure it works well for you. I know this is hard.  We all hated this "in-between" area.  Once you get a firm diagnosis, and then a plan, you will begin to get your arms around this thing.  But what they are proposing is exactly what is commonly done in your situation.  The thinking behind the mast vs the lumpectomy, is that if there are two that they have identified, there may be more in there they don't see.  Does not mean there is or that it is extra dangerous.  Has no impact on your survival stats.  It is just another rock in this nasty, rocky, road. Gentle hugs, Shirlann

Posts.Content: Jan 1, 2009 07:51PM Shirlann wrote: It is a bit of a hard decision, one they very graciously let YOU make, dang their hides.  But I had a lumpectomy with radiation and that was 10 years ago and overall, I am very glad I did.  Be careful when you read the posts, no one comes on and says, "I had rads, worked the whole time, did not burn, am fine now"  This is me. Posts.Content: Jul 24, 2008 02:09PM Shirlann wrote: Hi Falco, everyone on this site is pretty pro-active, both from some bad experiences or from knowing you are the only one who truly gives a damn what happens to you.  (not counting, of course, beloved relatives and friends). I would sort've agree with the "wait and see" except for the family history.  With this in mind, keep pushing until you get better answers.  I don't like the lump near your chest wall, they are harder to treat and keep track of.  The ONLY way to be sure of what is in these lumps, after they pass the cyst test with ultra-sound, is the actual tissue under a microscope.  You will get resistance, but you need to emphasize the family history and if possible, get genetic testing to rule out the BRCA gene. Again, most younger women and some older women have dense breasts.  Well, the medical profession has to deal with that.  Just throwing up ones hands because they are frustrated just won't do. So while you are young and probably have nothing to worry about, keep after this until you are satisfied that you have been properly assessed. Gentle hugs, Shirlann
Posts.Title: Life sentence, even with no cancer? theonlyfalco AnnNYC

Posts.Content: Dec 7, 2007 08:11PM - edited Dec 7, 2007 08:11PM by Shirlann Hi honey, I doubt you could get an answer on that one. The problem is that with different women with different skin types, things are bound to be not the same. Younger women sometimes have "denser" breasts and lots of lumps. Older women, not so much. Too many variables to get a good reliable answer. And, even the professionals sometimes are wrong. You hear that if it moves, it is not cancer. This is not always true. You hear so much that if you are really worried, the only positive way to know what is going on with tissue is to put it under a microscope. Period. Everything else is guesswork, good guesswork, but still, guesswork. Gentle hugs, Shirlann
Posts.Title: What am I feeling here? newgirl77 Shirlann

Posts.Content: Aug 8, 2008 05:59PM Shirlann wrote: Hi Lainy, this is so hard.  Many of us have these waits and they are just miserable.  One thing to try is ask the facility to let you know in case of a cancellation.  Often, they will do that.  It is a good thing you got the original stuff done so fast. With most breast cancers, they are 8 to 10 years old before they can be found at all.  So this delay will most likely not harm you, just drive you nuts.  There are exceptions to this, of course, but generally, this is why they are not rushing around for you.  They used to do this, but studies have shown that this is not necessary. Ask the onc/surgeon/doc for some Ativan or Valium to tide you over the sleepless nights and the days of treatments.  They are a life saver.  If you seem to have a serious problem (I did, I am an anxiety/depressive) ask for an anti-depressant.  Many of us take them.  After a year or so, when you get your confidence back, you can slooowly get off them.  They are not addictive, but you musn't stop them abruptly.   By all means, calmly tell your sons.  And use the word cancer.  Only because they are like little antennas, they overhear phone conversations, they imagine things are much worse than they are and it makes life easier for you.  Tell them you will cry now and then, but you will get well.  This journey is so long, the normal process of "shielding" them from the truth just won't work, the treatment takes too long. If you are truly concerned, then either insist on a nearer date, or change providers.  You can get all your mammo's and slides and take them to another place.  Nothing but your insurance ties you to one place.  So if this is going to be a horrible issue, then move on. Keep posting and let us know how you are doing.  This site is marvelous.  We have women who I swear, know more than the docs, especially about the practical side of this journey. 80% of us recover completely, this is most likely you too.  So don't get too frantic.  I am almost 10 years post treatment and doing fine. Gentle hugs, Shirlann

Posts.Content: Jun 7, 2008 09:39PM Shirlann wrote: Hi Jason, stop right where you are and be assured that 90% of us breast cancer gals will be just fine. Now, if you want the best and easiest 2nd or 3rd opinion, this is what you do.  She has the mast or lumpectomy.  Then she has the lymph node study, either Sentinel Node (checking the first node) or removal of a group of nodes, whichever, all this tissue will be sent to a pathologist and she will get a report, or her doc/onc/surgeon will.  (She needs to start a file, beginning with a copy of this report). Now, when this work is all done, contact Sloan-Kettering, Dana Farber, Mayo Clinic, UCLA, any number or super-duper cancer centers.  Ask them what the charge is to re-do the slides and give a diagnosis.  They will tell you.  Ask where to send it.  Then, you collect the original mammograms, the original slides, and copies of her records and forward the whole thing Fed-Ex to the hospital you choose.  This is the best 2nd opinion you can get.  It is usually pretty reasonable.  They don't need your mom.  If the new stuff agrees with the old stuff, and the reports are the same, as well as the treatment recommendations, you are probably good to go with the original group.  If things differ, send the stuff to another GOOD cancer center. There is no mad rush.  Most breast cancers, when large enough to be found by any means, are 8 to 12 years old.  So several weeks of careful thinking with good info is very reasonable.  I would immediately buy Dr. Susan Love's Breast Book, I wore mine out.  Read only as far as you need to, the later chapters are scary and you won't need them. I took a small tape recorder to all the meetings.  You are under (your mom) such a lot of strain and fear, it is hard to remember, and they throw a whole lot of stuff at you.  This way, you can re-play the tape and be sure you know what they suggest. This is a long, drawn out journey.  But your mom will survive.  In the old days, breast cancer was almost untreatable, but today, most of us will live to be very old.  So stop being depressed.  Think of this as your thesis.  A long journey, but most likely good news at the end and a war story for the whole family in years to come. Post often, we will help all we can, I am 9 & 1/2 years post treatment and just fine.  Most of the women I met here when I was first diagnosed are just fine too, we stay in touch. I am now 72, I was 63 when diagnosed.  I only had a lumpectomy and radiation and I worked through the whole thing.  So don't collapse, you will be fine.  Come back often with any questions, we have wonderful women and a few husbands and sons who will help you all we can. Gentle hugs, Shirlann

Posts.Content: Jul 6, 2008 06:46PM - edited Jul 6, 2008 06:52PM by Shirlann Hi Charmed, well, one thing you can stop worrying about, they will NEVER do a general anesthetic without you not eating after 12 midnight, so unless they told you to not eat, you can forget the general.  They might do another test, but all the others either need no anesthetic, or just a local, like a tooth job.  So stop worrying about that one thing. I had a stereotactic, it was not bad at all, but they missed my cancer.  So while they very often work very well, this test did not work on me. As far as having your friend with you for everything, obviously, he/she can't be with you for any x-ray tests, since even the techs leave, and for me at least, and I am married 55 years, I would rather flip my boobies out with just another woman there, not my hubby (I am not too proud of my body).  But my hubby always takes me and waits in whatever place they put him.  Never hurts to ask, but some of the rooms are rather tiny, and that can be an issue.  As far as being able to know exactly what is happening, this could be what is going on.  They do a diagnostic mammo, and see something or not.  If they do, they often send you to ultrasound, and if that is telling them your "thingy" is a cyst, In my case, that would have been the end of it.  Since my Ultrasound showed solid, I went on to another test.  This could be why no one can tell you exactly what is going to happen is because one thing depends on the other.  Good luck, gentle hugs, Shirlann

Posts.Content: Jan 26, 2012 03:14PM Shirlann wrote: Slow down, dear sister, don't get ahead of yourself.  I have seen many  a woman with 10cm tumors that do just fine.  It is torture waiting for the sloooow march of medicine through this early part, but remember, 80% of us recover.  I am 13 years post treatment and fine.  There are literally thousands of women who are well after treatment.  I had a small bible study group of about 22 women, and I blubberingly told them I had BC.  I was utterly astonished when 3 of them had BC too.  One was 22 yesrs out, one 11 and one 7, and, yes, they are still alive today. I had cancer of the hair, the big toe, the elbow, during the early days, EVERY little thing is cancer, well, it isn't. Ask your doc/onc for Xanax or Valium and set one by your bed with a glass of water, when the squirrels start running around the ceiling at about 2 to 3am, grab it quick.  I took one before each meeting, treatment, etc.  Get through this as easily as you can.  Don't suffer when you don't need to. YOU WILL BE FINE! Gentle hugs, Shirlann

Posts.Content: Sep 2, 2008 06:20PM - edited Sep 2, 2008 06:22PM by Shirlann Hi Kerimarie and Bluedasher, try not to stress out too much (easier said than done), remember, about 80% of us go through treatment and are just fine.  I am 10 years post treatment and just got back from a trip 1300 miles up the Amazon. This s not real easy, but don't get caught up in too much gloom and doom.  You should do just fine.  Most of us do.  All the women I started out with are moving on with their lives, seldom post and are my dear friends. You don't get a lot of:  "I had breast cancer, was treated, and am just fine".  No one posts that.  But it is very often true, just not too interesting.  I met a lady at the dog park she had BC in 1985 and told me she often forgets which side it was on!  So I don't mean to minimize this, it is scary, but just think, President Ford's wife had it and Happy Rockefeller had it (she was the Veep's wife)(way back in the 70's)  both men are not dead, the women are fine.  Nancy Reagan had it, he is gone, she is fine.  Shirley Temple had it many years ago, Sheryl Crowe, Melissa Etheridge, Edie Falco, Dorothy Hamill (our Olympic skater, so much for staying in shape) and so many others who are long, long time survivors, it boggles the mind. Oh and the cute little aussie singer who did the musical with John Travolta, dang, her name escapes me. Keep posting, someone is always around and you have joined a super sisterhood! Gentle hugs, Shirlann

Posts.Content: Aug 7, 2008 02:14PM - edited Aug 7, 2008 02:16PM by Shirlann Oh definitely, in the short term, as your providers suggest, go for the checks.  This is just good medicine on their part and a logical and intelligent thing for you to do on your part. But don't let fear dominate your life.  Half the women probably have something in their breasts to worry about, but they don't because they weren't smart as your were to have things checked.  So just forget it, put it on the calendar, as you would a pap smear, go do the checks until they say "all clear", to go back to once a year.   Then congratulate yourself on being a very smart, intelligent person. However, if you are going to worry, then see the surgeon.  Nothing wrong with that.  Just another level of looking.   Gentle hugs, Shirlann

Posts.Title: Absolutely Terrified needhope Racy

Posts.Content: Jun 4, 2008 02:14PM - edited Jun 4, 2008 02:14PM by Shirlann Hi luckylady, I was 63 when diagnosed.  I am 73 now (in two weeks) and for me, the treatment was very doable.  You have choices, too.  Once you get your diagnosis, you can DO whatever you want.  If they recommend chemo, you can decline.  But a simple lumpectomy with radiation as I had, was nothing.  (Others do have worse experiences).  But do not assume anything or reject treatment out of hand, without knowing what is going on. You can have the tumor removed and just do the hormone pills, or, have the tumor removed and just do the radiation.  There is no one forcing you to do anything.  It is always your choice. But to not even find out if you can live another 10 or 15 years, with minimal treatment, if foolish. By the way, this is a very ugly, nasty way to die, nothing like the movies, where they sigh, lay back on the pillows, and go to sleep. I don't mean to be cruel, but I remember as a child, people spoke of breast cancer in whispers, it was so awful.  NOT SO TODAY! So do go for your checks, find out what it up, listen to the recommendations, then do whatever you are comfortable with Gentle hugs, Shirlann

Posts.Content: Jan 10, 2008 03:00PM Shirlann wrote: Hi good son, do not panic, 90% of us will recover from breast cancer and do just fine, it just scares everyone silly.  Perfectly normal.  I would get Dr. Susan Love's Breast Book.  Don't necessarily give it to your mom, but read yourself and you will understand her path report and other things so much better. I took a small tape recorder to all appointments.  Then, at her leisure, she can review what was said, and consult with you. The docs/oncs usually want your mom to make a lot of decisions.  So you having some information will help her and what you don't understand you can come here, or look up in the book. Don't feel alone, and don't consider this a death sentence, it is not.  I am 9 years post treatment, and just fine, and I met a lady at the dog park a couple of years ago.  She had BC in 1985 and told me laughingly that she often forgets which side it was on. I don't mean to make light of this.  It is often a scary and nasty and worst of all, looooong journey.  Not what we are used to.  But she can do this, with your help and love. Gentle hgus, Shirlann

Posts.Content: Nov 23, 2007 06:34PM - edited Nov 23, 2007 06:36PM by Shirlann Hi Ilenee, welcome to this site. Sorry you had to join us, but we are a fighting bunch of women! Stage one is marvelous. At some point they probably will check your lymph nodes and of course, you will get the results of the pathology report. Ask for a copy, and start a small file. Also, I took a small tape recorder with me to the meetings and did not have to take notes. I liked Dr. Susan Love's Breast Book, just read as far as you need to, the later chapters are scary, and you won't need them. Unless things have changed (and they do change) if you have no positive nodes, you may not have to have chemo, I did not. My cancer was 7mm and I had no positive nodes, so I had a lumpectomy and radiation, worked through the whole thing. You will be fine. 90% of us recover and go on with our lives. I am 9 years post treatment and doing fine. So try not to get to upset, come here and post often, this is where you will get the support and comfort you need. Gentle hugs, Shirlann

Posts.Content: Sep 1, 2008 01:52PM - edited Sep 1, 2008 01:55PM by Shirlann First of all, please know you are so welcome on this board.  And also, accept my sincere sorrow for this terrible news. Most breast cancers are in us for from 8 to 12 years before they can be detected by any means.  So don't feel that this just popped up.  What happened is it just got big, very fast.  Obviously, the first biopsy missed the spot.  And there are occasions where things do go this fast.  But it is no one's fault. Neither hers, or the providers.  A month ago would not have made much difference in this sad outcome. Now, please know that many women live for quite some time with metastases.  They will treat her with chemo and with radiation.  Remember Lance Armstrong, had testicular cancer, with mets to the lung and brain.  He underwent very heavy duty chemo and is alive today, 11 years later.  Now breast cancer is nastier than testicular, so a cure is unlikely, but she could well live several years.   Remember Elizabeth Edwards.  She is still here and running her house and doing okay, despite having a diagnosis of metastasis.  So hope is still with you. Down lower, there is a thread for recurrence and metastases.  You might want to look there, Many wonderful women who have dealt with the same issues your sister will have post there, and they have wonderful advice and help.  However, you are welcome anyplace on this site. I am so sorry, gentle hugs, Shirlann

Posts.Content: Mar 23, 2008 04:44PM - edited Mar 23, 2008 04:47PM by Shirlann Hi sister, my advice is to tell your little one that you have cancer. Then tell him you and dad are worried, but you KNOW you will be just fine. Tell him don't be scared if he sees you crying or without hair, or whatever, that as a family, you will get through this and be fine. Tell him everyone has to help, he needs to feed the dog, help fold the clothes, take out the trash, that together, you are strong. The reason for using the word, is he will hear it. And he needs to hear it first from you, not from eavesdropping on a phone conversation. Those little ears are antennas. Some of the younger women have told their children's teachers. Not that they want them to say much, just so they are aware of what is going on at home. Now to happier thoughts. 90% of us will be just fine. I am 9 years post treatment and have many friends that are further past treatment than that. Chances are excellent you will make a full recovery. My favorite story was several years ago a woman had the "family talk", and after she and her husband finished, they told the kids when things were normal again, they would all go to Disneyland, their littlest one ran out on the front porch and shouted to all the neighbors, "My mom has cancer and we are going to Disneyland!". They just broke up laughing. My mom's best friend just died at 94, 44 years post double mastectomy. And my mom died of a stroke 12 years ago. We all felt so sorry for Frances. I met a lady at the dog park who also has had breast cancer and it was in 1985. She said she sometimes forgets which side it was on. I don't mean to make light of this disease. It is hard, long and at times, nasty. But most of us will survive and live to be old ladies. Gentle hugs, Shirlann
Posts.Title: Diag 3/11/08 Sable Shirlann

Posts.Content: Sep 1, 2008 04:32PM Shirlann wrote: Oh yes, first of all the surgeon told me "You don't have breast cancer, your lump is smooth, and breast cancer is spikey".  Then 2 years later, when it was obvious to everyone that something was wrong, I had a stereotactic biopsy that missed the lump completely, then an open biopsy, which showed cancer.  They thought it was lymphoma.  They sent the slides to White Plains, NY, where I was finally diagnosed with Medullary BC, a small, sub-type, that is characterized by "smooth edges".  When I, by now thoroughly disgusted, picked up my mammo's and slides to go to UCLA, the mammo with the original "lump" was gone and the report the surgeon wrote had been re-written. So, get thee post haste to a breast clinic.  Demand a biopsy.  I don't know where they get off with this "wait and see".  The sooner you get a specialist involved, the better. By the way, Brigham & Women's is one of the best in the country.  You will be in good hands. Gentle hugs, Shirlann PS:  6 months, my rearend, if it was his testicle, he would be in there for a biopsy in 30 minutes!

Posts.Content: Nov 27, 2007 06:58PM - edited Nov 27, 2007 07:02PM by Shirlann Hi dear, you show no evidence of Metastases, that is "mets", so stop worrying about that. If it ever happened, it would be way down the road, and will most likely never happen. I would get Dr. Susan Love's Breast Book, I don't think ILC is rare, I had Medullary breast cancer, which only 5% of the breast cancers are this type. (clumsy sentence, sorry). But that doesn't mean much. With Dr. Love's Book, just read as far as you need to, the later chapters you will never use and they will just scare you. Take a small tape recorder so you don't have to take notes. If all your scans and other tests came out good, then forget Mets. That is what mets are, cancer that has gone elsewhere. I presume, with multi-focal cancer, you will have a mastectomy? Sounds right, then chemo and radiation. You probably will have hormone therapy, because you are ER+ & PR +, this is a good thing, but happens later, when all the other treatment is over. But in any case, this is waaay down the road, don't worry about this part now. This stupid disease is done in stages, which drives us all to drink. Slowly they move through the series of tests, treatment options are discussed, and you slowly go nuts. But when the whole picture becomes clear, all of it makes a lot more sense. Sounds to me like you have a good diagnostic team. Many of your worries they will answer eventually. Just have to play the waiting game and see what turns up. I am 9 years post treatment, am ER and PR Negative, am doing fine and almost went crazy with the slow, step by step "dance" that breast cancer requires. Do remember that MOST, not all, but MOST breast cancers when large enough to be found by any means are 8 to 12 years old. So a panicky rush is not the way to go. So what part of the recommendations so far are you reconsidering? I am just curious. Gentle hugs, Shirlann

Posts.Title: Absolutely Terrified needhope Racy

Posts.Content: Feb 10, 2011 06:15PM Shirlann wrote: It is interesting that you finally said what we all know, who have been through this frickin' nightmare.  The road is so loooooong.  Takes forever.  Make an appt., go to appt., get tests, wait for tests, then go to someone else, make appt., go to appt., get tests, wait for results, make another appt.  yada, yada, yada.  No one's fault, but soooo tiring both medically and physicall, and most of all emotionally just draining. We have all been right where you are.  But believe me, there is a light at the end of the tunnel.  I am 12 years plus through treatment and now it is just another war story.  Just a horrible long one.  Most of us end up with PTSD, why not?  It is just the same as the vets, will we live?  Will we be able to work?, who will take care of the kids and hubby?, who will fix Christmas dinner? This is a long, hard, terrifying and endless journey.  Your best friends are right here, don't even TRY to talk to anyone else, they will only make you mad.  Some say, "Oh, my aunt had that, and she is just fine!"  (Oh really, she is not me, (be sure no sharp instuments are around with this one).  Then, the others, who look at you and ask you if you have all your affairs in order!  Don't know which ones to hate the most. Even your nearest and dearest.  I love,  "Well your are done with treatment, and you are fine!"  Going into the details that you never KNOW for sure you are fine until you die of something else, is just too much.  But you can't say that to all these people.  So, come here, cry, laugh, tell us all your fears, we are your new best friends.  It is such a blessing. Gentle hugs, Shirlann
Posts.Title: Tired...I want off this ride... pejkug3 NSWTD

Posts.Content: Oct 9, 2012 01:59PM Shirlann wrote: Whoa, honey, I am 14 years post diagnosis and just fine.  About 80% of BC gals recover.  It is a hard year and scares you silly, but you both can do this and you have every reason to be pretty sure your mom will be fine.  It took my bunch of yokels 3 months to diagnose me, I was half crazy.  It takes 12 years for a breast cancer to be found by ANY means, so a few weeks means nothing except in a few rare types.  Come and ask questions, there are wonderful gals here to help you, it is a wonderful lifeline.  One thing you learn real quick is that the medical profession plods along like molasses.  Remember, Shirley Temple had BC, so did Betty Ford, Melissa Etheridge, Cheryl Crowe, that singer from Australia, so, so many, Robin from one of the early shows.  All these gals are fine, some, like Shirley Temple are 29 years post treatment.   So post often, we care about you. Gentle hugs, Shirlann

Posts.Content: Nov 28, 2007 06:33PM - edited Nov 28, 2007 06:33PM by Shirlann Hi Robyn, I surely don't want to scare you, but on occasion dimpling is one of the symptoms of Inflammatory Breast Cancer. It probably is nothing, but you need to push ahead and have a qualified (hopefully breast specialist) see this. That is really reaching for trouble, but I would feel remiss if I didn't mention this very remote possiblity, so you can ask about it. Don't ever listen to techs when it comes to recommended treatment. Go when you feel you need to or when a licensed doc tells you to. While you don't want to fixate on things and drive yourself crazy with unecessary worries, you know your body better than anyone. Gentle hugs, Shirlann

Posts.Content: Dec 12, 2007 06:15PM Shirlann wrote: Humm, I sure was not impressed with my San Diego bunch.  But the Green Hospital of Scripps Clinic, is considered a superior facility. Remember, you can easily get all the preliminary work, i.e., biopsies, removals, and then, before treatment, contact Sloan-Kettering, Dana Farber, MAYO, UCLA, ask about cost, pack up your original slides, mammos and copies of your records, Fed-Ex the whole lot and get a new pathology report and treatment recommendation for not a lot of money. I did this at UCLA, because here at Sharp they thought I had Lymphoma, I was really scared.  Then, they sent my slides to White Plains, NY, and I had a small sub-type of breast cancer called Medullary.  NO ONE in this town, apparently, knew this.  I was not too impressed. So insurance often dictates what we can or cannot do, but you can always send your stuff off, and that is relatively cheap and you can get the best pathologists in the world, who do only breast cancers.  Some women do this more than once, if the diagnosis is unusual, as mine was. Oh, I did run into a really super oncologist in La Jolla, if you can go to him.  He is Dr. Millard.  He is the top of the field in San Diego.  If you have a PPO, this would work, but you can always call and ask the office what they will accept. Gentle hugs, Shirlann

Posts.Content: May 6, 2009 02:03PM - edited May 6, 2009 02:05PM by Shirlann Hi gals, what a lot of us have, due to rads, is Costochondritis, Dr. Susan Love mentions this in her book.  It is inflammation of the meat between the ribs.  Her "quick" diagnosis is to pinch the area, if it hurts like heck, it is probably Costochondritis (never use this as a "for sure" thing, always check with doc/onc). I have had this and it comes on sometimes several weeks after treatment ends, scaring you even sillier.   Certainly some women do have heart and lung damage, but this is truly quite rare. Oh, rad/oncs DENY everything.  I think they are trained that way.  They even told everyone that the slight form of radiation sickness most of us get (fatigue) did not exist.  HA, I was around for Nagasaki and Hiroshima, I know better. Gentle hugs, Shirlann

Posts.Content: Aug 18, 2008 04:00PM - edited Aug 18, 2008 04:01PM by Shirlann Well, first of all, you won the breast cancer lottery!  There is no better diagnosis.  You are not in danger of your life.  You will, of course, have to be super vigilant, but you will recover (none of us invasives can say that for sure) and resume your life. Radiologists, as a rule, do not give diagnosis, much less treatment opinions.  But who knows, different areas.  If you have a general practitioner you trust, then you start there.  I am sure your radiologist sends the reports to someone?  This person will recommend the other members of your team.  Then, you will usually see the surgeon next and an oncologist pretty much in that order.  I bought a cheap tape recorder and recorded all the visits so I did not have to take notes at the numerous appts. and I did not have to try and remember. Oh, you sound quite intelligent, so I would get Dr. Susan Love's Breast Book, to help with the terminology, etc.  It is very readable. This is just a guess, but I would think they would want to do a skin saving mastectomy, because the "thingys" are so multi-focal, or, in english, in more than one place.  But this is just a guess. I don't know what the TE-2 is, but more women will come along soon, and we have some that are real whizses with all the terms.  I am almost 10 years post treatment, so I don't have the latest info.  I am even forgetting what I had.  I have no idea how I got the ilalics, but bear with me.     So come often and post, we are always around.  You will be fine, gee, it feels so good to say that to someone! Gentle hugs, Shirlann
Posts.Title: Just Diagnosed DCIS & Need Members Advice G696 susan13

Posts.Content: Jan 30, 2008 04:23PM - edited Jan 30, 2008 04:24PM by Shirlann Hi MLM, I am a big believer in telling your child, and using the word cancer.  Of course, only age apropriate information.  Just say, "Mom has cancer in her breast.  The doctors are going to take it out and I will be fine.  But you may see me (whatever applies) without hair, crying, looking sad, but I will be just fine.  What I need you to do is (whatever you can think of) is help feed the dog, water the plants, help me fold the clothes, etc. whatever fits. The reason you need to say, "cancer", is he will hear it.  Trust me, you won't know he is listening to a phone conversation, you may cry, people will look worried.  This will scare him much worse than the honest truth, age appropriate, of course. They are little antennas, and this cancer thing is long.  Too long to keep it a secret. We had one family that sat their kids down and told them kinda what I suggested.  One of the little ones ran out on the porch and shouted to the whole neighborhood, "My mom has breast cancer and we are going to Disneyland!".  She was embarrased, but they had to laugh. Keeping this important an event a secret is next to impossible.  Betweeen relatives, phone calls, appointments, surgeries, etc., he will know and imagine awful things.  Be honest, it is best. Hugs, Shirlann  PS:  I am 9 years post treatment and just fine, thousands of us out here are the same, you will be too.

Posts.Content: Oct 15, 2007 12:14PM Shirlann wrote: Hi sister, it is highly unlikely that anything has happened, not to say it could not, but it is rare that BC moves very fast. Having said that, if you are still worried, go back to the doc, he is the one with all the knowledge and experience that we do not have. Now, several of us have had such strange goings on. Sometimes you are just listening more closely to the things your body does, and worrying about each and every one. Also, if you are thinking about your breast, you may be holding your body or spine, (you would not know this) in a strange way and actually causing aches and pains. But never feel bad about going in and asking. Most of the people who treat cancer are very kind about reassuring us. They do not mind multiple visits. They are used to this and are very helpful. So go back and see him/her again. Gentle hugs, Shirlann

Posts.Content: Jun 1, 2011 04:04PM Shirlann wrote: Hi sister, MD Anderson is a great facility but they no longer do long distance consults.  So, choose Sloan-Kettering, Mayo Clinic, Dana Farber, Johns Hopkins.  Call them, ask how much to re-do your pathology.  We did this with UCLA.  Then, they will want your original mammos and original slides and all reports.  You can get this stuff usually with a signed authorization, or your institute will send the things directly.  Then the chosen clinic will redo the pathology and send you their report and recommendation for treatment.  If both facilities agree, you are fine, some women go to more than one place. Gentle hugs, Shirlann

Posts.Content: Aug 25, 2008 07:51PM - edited Aug 25, 2008 07:52PM by Shirlann The reason you trust your second opinion, usually, is because it comes from a place like Sloan-Kettering, Dana Farber, or Johns Hopkins, the top cancer centers in the world.  They are large and have pathologists who do nothing but breast cancer.  Much more experienced, usually, than the local people. You wait till you get your surgery and then get copies of your pathology report and your original slides,original mammograms,  and send them all to the facility you choose.  Call them first to check price, addreses, etc. You will get a new pathology report and a treatment recommendation. You can do this to 2 or 3 more places, if you have disagreement on diagnosis or treatment.  I did this with UCLA and they agreed with my group, so I was comfortable going ahead.  But you can't really do anything until the surgery is done and the lymph nodes are checked. I would take a small tape recorder with you to each meeting, they tell you so much it is hard to write and listen.  Also, I like Dr. Susan Love's Breast Book, easy to understand. Ask for Ativan or Valium, if you don't have anything like this, and take one the days of appts. or treatments.  It eases the raveled sleeve of care...... Post often, someone is always around, Gentle hugs, Shirlann
